title: TypeScript server crashes with out of memory exception
body:
### üîé Search Terms

"TypeScript server", "OOM", "memory", "out of memory exception"

### üïó Version Information

TypeScript version: 5.7.2
VS Code version: 1.96.3

### üíª Description

I am working on a large platform that provides APIs for users to call. Since most of the implementation is not in JavaScript, we provide declaration (`d.ts`) files with classes and methods so that users programming in JavaScript can have IntelliSense & type inference. However, the platform has been steadily growing over the years and now for the `d.ts` files we provide, there are over 7000 classes, and each class on average has over 100 methods.

### üôÅ Actual behavior

When the user is using VS Code and relying on the TypeScrpt server shipped as part of VS Code for IntelliSense and type inference, the TypeScript server processes exits. I can reproduce this while in debug mode and can see the error is due to `Out of memory exception`.

### üôÇ Expected behavior

The TypeScript server process should not have exceeded its total maximum heap memory.

### Additional information about the issue

On my computer, I am able to increase the memory used by TypeScript server using these VS Code settings:
```json
    "typescript.tsserver.maxTsServerMemory": 8192,
    "typescript.tsserver.nodePath": "node",
```
However, this cannot be done for specific customers who are using much weaker computers, such as computers with 8 GB RAM. The total size of all our `d.ts` files are 91 MB, but profiling the TypeScript server process shows that loading all the `d.ts` files (excluding node_modules and all other declaration files) results in ~ 4 GB of heap memory used. This seems odd because that is over 40:1 ratio of heap memory to file size, which seems very high.

The contents of the `d.ts` files are very primitive, they all have a `declare class` with no `extends` or inheritance structure and have only fields and methods:
```ts
declare class ApiName {
  field1: string;
  field2: string;
  static function1(): string;
  static function2(): string;
  // etc.........
}
```
All our users are developing in JavaScript (not TypeScript) so they are using a `jsconfig.json` with the following contents
```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ES6",
    "lib": [
      "ES2015"
    ],
    "checkJs": false,
    "strictNullChecks": true
  },
  "include": [
    "./src/**/*.js",
    "./path to our dts files",
  ]
}
```
I understand that this use case is kind of a stress test of TypeScript server, but hopefully creating this issue would reveal some improvements in terms of memory and if there is anything I can configure on my end for optimizations.
author: c3danielxu

comments.body: We've optimized our memory footprint to the highest extent possible; if you're only seeing memory consumption as a linear output of input source size, there isn't an actionable bug here. We could possibly advise on specific optimizations to be made in the .d.ts files if we can look at them.

> This is the current best representation we have found

Thanks for clarifying. In that case, I'll look into if we can decrease some of the repetition for methods that were declared on 2+ classes.

Do you know if it is possible to have lazy/incremental loading of some sort in TypeScript? For example, there are groups of users who use different sets of classes, but none of them end up using all 7000 classes in their codebase. And in a given development session, the user probably uses even less APIs for intellisense, although we don't know what the user may or may not use.

Is it possible for something like, load methods of a class into memory once it has been determined that we need to know about the class?

There isn't any way to "lazy" load a file, since any file could potentially contain a declaration that affects something else.

If you only use `import` statements to bring files into scope, then only the files imported (and their transitive imports) will be loaded, but then it'd be required for users to explicitly import their API subset. There isn't a way to "un-load" a file after it's already been explicitly included through whatever mechanism but not used, though a file that is not actually referenced tends to have minimal impact on memory footprint (presuming there's a reasonable number of them, of course).

That makes sense, that would explain why nothing came up with "lazy" loading when searching through TypeScript docs. Unfortunately all our APIs are available to user on the global scope so we can't leverage `require`/`import` capabilities for limiting the files.

Usually for optimizations there are large areas of improvement before diminishing returns occurs so I was hoping there might be something we could do in TypeScript server, but if as you said there isn't that much room for improvement, then we might be out of luck and need to resort to other measures within my organization's codebase.

Thanks @RyanCavanaugh for your responses, it is really appreciated!

author: schizobulia

comments.body: Yes - why wouldn't it?

> Yes - why wouldn't it?

Can I ask why it is designed this way? üòÄ  @RyanCavanaugh

title: Type of a generic is not narrowed
author: Nlicro

comments.body: This is working as intended. You do not specify the type parameter for `C` in your `test` function, so it falls back to the default `Tag`. That means the type is `C<Tag>`, which results in the type `{ tag: Tag, type: string | number | boolean }`. This is not a union type that can be narrowed.

> This is working as intended. You do not specify the type parameter for `C` in your `test` function, so it falls back to the default `Tag`. That means the type is `C<Tag>`, which results in the type `{ tag: Tag, type: string | number | boolean }`. This is not a union type that can be narrowed.

I'm sorry that my example is a little wrong and you misunderstood it. I have updated the code. 
I mean the type in the switch statement, not the return type of `test` function

> you misunderstood it.

I did not. The type of `instance` is `C<Tag>`, which results in the type `{ tag: Tag, type: string | number | boolean }`. It's **not** the type `{ tag: Tag.A, type: string } | { tag: Tag.B, type: number } | { tag: Tag.C, type: boolean }`, so it can't be narrowed the way you expect it to. It's perfectly valid to have the value `{ tag: Tag.A, type: true }` assigned to `C<Tag>`.

This approach is unsafe, as it does not align with your types. Again, `{ tag: tag.A, type: true }` is a perfectly valid assignment to the type `C`, but using your `isTagA` type guard it would wrongly assume the type of `type` is `string`, when it's actually `boolean`.

You seem to wrongly assume that `InterfaceByTag[T]["type"]` is a type depending on what's assigned to `tag`, but that's not the case. The type depends on whatever `T` is, which can be a union type as well - and actually is a union type when your type argument defaults to `Tag`.

You need to use a union of the types you want:
- `C<Tag.A> | C<Tag.B> | C<Tag.C>`, which results in `{ tag: Tag.A, type: string } | { tag: Tag.A, type: number } | { tag: Tag.C, type: boolean }`
- **not** `C<Tag>` or `C` (they're the same), which results in `{ tag: Tag, type: string | number | boolean }`

You could use a helper type and make use of distributive conditional types to get a union based on your tags: `type AllTagC<T extends Tag> = T extends Tag ? C<T> : never`  
Then use it: `function test(instance: AllTagC<Tag>) { ... }`

It's crucial to understand what structure your types actually look like.
This issue has been marked as "Question" and has seen no recent activity. It has been automatically closed for house-keeping purposes.

title: Understanding type checker cache
author: JesusTheHun

comments.body:
> Is there a way to measure improvement made on cache usage ? I assume --extendedDiagnostics will show less instantiations, right ?

Correct; the counts here are a good proxy for how much work is being saved/not-saved

> Will the cache be used to evaluate `Result1bis` ? What about `Result2` ? It's a different alias but it's exactly the same type.

There's no interning of "identical" object types, so computations on `Arg1` and `Arg2` will be independent (literal types *are* interned). Identical instantiations are cached, so `Result1` and `Result1bis` will point to the same type.

> In this scenario, will the cache be used when evaluating Result2 ? `Describe<'hi'>` has already been evaluated before for Result1, so that step uses cache, right ?

Yes (because literal types are interned)

> Is there any particular condition that would prevent hitting the cache ?

This is pretty vague; I don't know how to give a useful answer

> Yes (because literal types are interned)

So the following wouldn't hit the cache because the type arguments are objects ?

```ts
type Result3 = DescribeAll<[{ title: string }, { tags: string[] }]>;
```

> This is pretty vague; I don't know how to give a useful answer

For example, for tail recursive evaluation to take place, the following conditions need to be met :

> We tail-recurse for generic conditional types that (a) have not already been evaluated and cached, and
(b) are non distributive, have a check type that is unaffected by instantiation, or have a non-union check
type. Note that recursion is possible only through aliased conditional types, so we only increment the tail
This issue has been marked as "Question" and has seen no recent activity. It has been automatically closed for house-keeping purposes.

Come on @typescript-bot ! Unlike you, humans need to rest !

For the following code, the number of instantiation increases by 4 each type I compute `AsArray<Arg1>`. 

```ts
type Arg1 = { title: string };

type AsArray<T> = T extends unknown ? [T] : never;

type Result1 = AsArray<Arg1>; // Instantiations : 4
type Result2 = AsArray<Arg1>; // Instantiations : 8
type Result3 = AsArray<Arg1>; // Instantiations : 12
```

I expected the number of instantiation to stay exactly the same, but apparently the evaluation it's not skipped entirely.
So I ran the following :

```ts
type Describe<T> = T extends string
  ? `string: ${T}`
  : T extends number
    ? `number: ${T}`
    : `unknown`;

type DescribeAll<T extends ReadonlyArray<unknown>> = T extends [infer A, ...infer Rest]
  ? Describe<A> | DescribeAll<Rest>
  : never;

// 29 instantiations

type Result1 = DescribeAll<['hi']>; // + 42 (71)
type Result2 = DescribeAll<['hi']>; // + 13 (84)
type Result3 = DescribeAll<['hi']>; // + 13 (97)
type Result4 = DescribeAll<['John']>; // + 22 (119)
type Result5 = DescribeAll<['Doe']>; // + 22 (141)

type Obj = { title: string };
type Obj2 = { title: string };

type Result6 = DescribeAll<[Obj]>; // + 22 instantiations (163)
type Result7 = DescribeAll<[Obj]>; // + 15 instantiations (178)
type Result8 = DescribeAll<[Obj2]>; // + 22 instantiations (200)
```

So it looks like some things are cached. The first call to `DescribeAll` triggers `42` instantiations while subsequent calls with the same parameter cost only `13`. Calls with a new string parameter cost `22` so I guess out of the `42` instantiations required to evaluate the type, 13 can't ever be cached, and 9 needs to be evaluate for each new parameter met.

> So the following wouldn't hit the cache because the type arguments are objects ?

Correct, type literals will get their own ID and thus be a cache miss.

At the level of analysis you're doing here, I'd recommend setting a few breakpoints in tsc and stepping through it. It'll be much more instructive (and accurate!) than my prose.

title: ts.createSourceFile trims leading newlines, causing stored line numbers to mismatch
body: ### üîé Search Terms createSourceFile newlines trim ### üïó Version & Regression Information - This is the behavior in every version I tried, and I reviewed the FAQ for entries about createSourceFile ### ‚èØ Playground Link _No response_ ### üíª Code ```ts import React from 'react'; export default function HelloWorldView() { return Hello; } ``` ### üôÅ Actual behavior Given this TSX file, React tooling will store a source reference on the `` element as e.g. ``` $0.__reactFiber$wzqrbgzp6o._debugSource ``` and it will contain ``` { columnNumber: 10, fileName: ".../something.tsx", lineNumber: 7 } ``` However, if you feed the TSX file into `ts.createSourceFile` and look for an element on line 7, you will not find anything because the file has been changed to ``` import React from 'react'; export default function HelloWorldView() { return Hello; } ``` and it only has 5 lines ### üôÇ Expected behavior ts.createSourceFile does no transformations whatsoever on the given input ### Additional information about the issue _No response_

title: TypeScript only find types
author: regseb

comments.body:
`types` in `exports` section override/shadow `import`/`require` and in your declarations you only export type.

To export value you need to declare const and export it as default IIRC
If you're already using TypeScript, you'd be better of using it to produce your declaration files instead of doing it by hand; it would have done the right thing.

- must export typed JavaScript objects.

---

title: ts.ImportDeclaration.moduleSpecifier can`t run  getText(), because node don`t have parent.
author: ouyangxuxiang

comments.body: You can just call `element.name.getText(sourceFile);` to work around your problem. TS doesn't always set up `.parent` references on the parsed nodes - it usually happens in the binder.

Yeah, you either need to pass the flag to the parser to set parents, or pass in the source file. Both of these are performance related things (many transformers don't need parents, and walking up the parents every single time is slow).

title: (Is it possible to | please provide a way to) specify the main module in a System-JS "outFile" bundle?
body:
### Acknowledgement

- [X] I acknowledge that issues using this template may be closed without further explanation at the maintainer's discretion.

### Comment

When loading a bundle of several modules in a browser, System-JS only "executes" the first one, unless there a call to System.import later, e.g. in the page itself. By executing, I mean running the global statements in the source .ts file.

The trouble is that - unless I'm mistaken - it doesn't seem possible to specify which module will be bundled first in the file specified with an "outFile" option. I tried to change the "main" property in the corresponding package.json but it has no effect.

comments.body: We nearly cut SystemJS `outFile` support in 5.0. I'd recommend switching to a more-configurable bundler if you need functionality beyond what's already available.

title: tsc target did not work expectedly when compile ES2022 to ES2015
body:

target  ES2022  ES2015

TS 4.5

### üíª Code

npx tsc --target es5 index.ts --outFile indexout.js


index.ts:
const arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
arr.at(1); // 2

### üôÅ Actual behavior

indexout.js:

const arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
arr.at(1); // 2

### üôÇ Expected behavior

Array.at is a new feature in ES2022
The target is ES5, the output js should not include Array.at
so the indexout.js can not work on the old browser.

_No response_
author: turtleinspace1

comments.body: TypeScript will only downlevel newer syntax. If the function you're trying to call does not exist at your runtime it's your responsibility to polyfill it.

title: Uncaught SyntaxError ":" in recursive function signature
author: peternroth

comments.body: You are attemping to execute TypeScript without compiling it to JavaScript, hence the error on the `:` token. You'll need to run `tsc` and then execute its output, or use a tool such as `ts-node` or `tsx` to run your script directly.
Thanks, jakebailey!

title: Allow to use value as type in some cases
author: buryndin

comments.body:
You should follow issue template.

There may be intersection between identifiers in types "scope" and values "scope", therefore it's not easier to get problems when values are used as types and vice versa.

Error message suggests correct fix - just write `typeof type` instead of plain `type`. Why it's problem to add explicit `typeof`?

TS would then report proper errors in your code In your code (after adding requested `typeof`).

I need not a 'typeof'. I pass type as parameter and I want to use this type.
typeof A === 'function' - it is useless.
I understand that we cannot use type as value, because some kind of types ('type' or 'interface') does not exist in runtime(compiled js-code). But It seems using value as type is quite possible.

Because you have explicit type `Function`. You should make that type generic (with constraint).

Also type of `type` is constructor type as you expect function and pass class constructor.
You should use `InstanceType<typeof type>` to get type you are looking for.

> You should use InstanceType<typeof type>
> It is not working:

You've skipped first part where it should be generic, but as **wisecerberus** mentioned, in that case you can just use generic `T` type instead of `typeof type`. Or as posted above by **MartinJohns**

> if predicate isTypeOf is true I expect that ... typeof list[0] = A

That's literally just `list[0] instanceof A`.  Martin's version is the correct way to implement your custom version.
Sorry guys, I forgot about generic. Thank's a lot for your help. Issue can be closed.

title: Update from 4.6.0-Beta to 4.6.1-RC introduced bug with Electron 12
body:
# Bug Report

After updating and compiling the project, the Electron-App (Runniing on Electron v12.0.2) does not load the resulting javascript file but reports an error just a view lines into the code.
`Uncaught SyntaxError: Unexpected token '{'`

### üîé Search Terms

`Uncaught SyntaxError: Unexpected token '{'` Electron 4.6.1-RC

### üïó Version & Regression Information

After update from 4.5.0-Beta to 4.6.2, did some research to find it was introduced with 4.6.1-RC

- This is a crash
- This changed between versions 4.6.0-Beta and 4.6.1-RC


### üíª Code

<!-- Please post the relevant code sample here as well-->
```ts
    class DebugConsole extends FudgeCore.DebugTarget {
        static { this.delegates = {                                                    // error thrown from this line
            [FudgeCore.DEBUG_FILTER.INFO]: console.info,
            [FudgeCore.DEBUG_FILTER.LOG]: console.log,
            [FudgeCore.DEBUG_FILTER.WARN]: console.warn,
            [FudgeCore.DEBUG_FILTER.ERROR]: console.error,
            [FudgeCore.DEBUG_FILTER.FUDGE]: DebugConsole.fudge,
            [FudgeCore.DEBUG_FILTER.CLEAR]: console.clear,
            [FudgeCore.DEBUG_FILTER.GROUP]: console.group,
            [FudgeCore.DEBUG_FILTER.GROUPCOLLAPSED]: console.groupCollapsed,
            [FudgeCore.DEBUG_FILTER.GROUPEND]: console.groupEnd,
            [FudgeCore.DEBUG_FILTER.SOURCE]: DebugConsole.source
        }; }
```

Previous output, which Electron12 was able to run, was
```ts
    class DebugConsole extends FudgeCore.DebugTarget {
          ....
    }
    DebugConsole.delegates = {
            [FudgeCore.DEBUG_FILTER.INFO]: console.info,
             ....
```

### üôÅ Actual behavior

Electron aborts loading the compiled Javascript file and throws the error 

### üôÇ Expected behavior

Load the compiled file and run it
author: JirkaDellOro

comments.body: Hmm, are you using `--target esnext`? If so, that isn't a stable output target across different versions of TypeScript, and will emit syntax that may be newer than what your engine expects. In this case, I would expect `--target es2020` would be good enough. Otherwise, we need more info about what went wrong (e.g. compiler options and new output).

Wow, didn't expect that quick of an answer. Correct, I used `esnext` to target whatever the newest is, but until I find the time to port the project to a newer Electron version, I just figured I can even use `es2021` with typescript@next. It's better this way round.

Thanks a lot!
No problem, glad the workaround was simple!

title: Values of array passed as parameter can't be used to infer the return type
body:
Not sure if this is a bug or an expected behavior so please forgive me if this does not belong here. I'm trying to create a factory that guarantees that the object it returns have certain properties, whose names are passed as parameters: ```ts const foo = fooFactory(['id', 'name']); // returned object is guaranteed by the type checker to implement the interface {id: string, name: string} ``` It's possible with the latest flavors of TypeScript by using something like this: ```ts const fooFactory1 =

(keys: ReadonlyArray): Record => { return; // noop for the sake of example } const keys= ['id', 'name']; const foo1 = fooFactory1(keys); // inferred type of foo1 is Record<"id" | "name", string>, as expected ``` But it seems like trying to infer the return type from the type of the parameter passed to the function instead of explicitely, like above doesn't work: ```ts const fooFactory2 = (keys: ReadonlyArray): Record => { return; // noop for the sake of example } const foo2 = fooFactory2(['id', 'name']); // inferred type of foo2 is Record ``` From my understanding, the two approachs should be analoguous: in the first case, the return type is inferred from the values of the `keys` array _passed_ as parameter, in the second case it should be inferred from the values of the `keys` array _received_ as parameter. Obviously the second approach is less verbose and doesn't require that the `keys` array is instanciated before being passed as parameter, so I hoped it would work. Am I doing anything wrong? Is it simply not supported? Or is it a bug? Thanks by advance.
author: ericmorand

comments.body: Reasonable question; the difference you've outlined here is exactly the difference between a generic and a non-generic function. In `fooFactory2`, the type `typeof keys[number]` refers only to the *parameter declaration*'s type, whereas in `fooFactory1`, `P` refers to the type of the argument as passed during the call. That's what makes a generic function generic: resolution of types is deferred to each call site, rather than being statically resolved.
Make a lot of sense. Thanks for the clarification.

title: [Question or Bug]: is the way of using ParsingContext intended in Parser.ts?
body:
> these happens in typescript repository itself.

Hi, I found an enum `ParsingContext` which is not defined as flags. Here are the code copy:
``` ts
        const enum ParsingContext {
            SourceElements,            // Elements in source file
            BlockStatements,           // Statements in block
            SwitchClauses,             // Clauses in switch statement
            SwitchClauseStatements,    // Statements in switch clause
            TypeMembers,               // Members in interface or type literal
            ClassMembers,              // Members in class declaration
            EnumMembers,               // Members in enum declaration
            HeritageClauseElement,     // Elements in a heritage clause
            VariableDeclarations,      // Variable declarations in variable statement
            ObjectBindingElements,     // Binding elements in object binding list
            ArrayBindingElements,      // Binding elements in array binding list
            ArgumentExpressions,       // Expressions in argument list
            ObjectLiteralMembers,      // Members in object literal
            JsxAttributes,             // Attributes in jsx element
            JsxChildren,               // Things between opening and closing JSX tags
            ArrayLiteralMembers,       // Members in array literal
            Parameters,                // Parameters in parameter list
            JSDocParameters,           // JSDoc parameters in parameter list of JSDoc function type
            RestProperties,            // Property names in a rest type list
            TypeParameters,            // Type parameters in type parameter list
            TypeArguments,             // Type arguments in type argument list
            TupleElementTypes,         // Element types in tuple element type list
            HeritageClauses,           // Heritage clauses for a class or interface declaration.
            ImportOrExportSpecifiers,  // Named import clause's import specifier list
            Count                      // Number of parsing contexts
        }
```
`as flags` means something like
```ts
enum Example{
A = 1<<0;
B = 1<<1;
}
```

But I see a strange use of it, which makes me feel they are used like flags.

```ts
            const saveParsingContext = parsingContext;
            parsingContext |= 1 << kind;   // `Line 1`
```
```ts
            switch (parsingContext) {
                case ParsingContext.ClassMembers:
                case ParsingContext.SwitchClauses:
                case ParsingContext.SourceElements:
                case ParsingContext.BlockStatements:
                case ParsingContext.SwitchClauseStatements:
                case ParsingContext.EnumMembers:
                case ParsingContext.TypeMembers:
                case ParsingContext.VariableDeclarations:
                case ParsingContext.JSDocParameters:
                case ParsingContext.Parameters:
                    return true;
            }
            return false;
```
```ts
        function isInSomeParsingContext(): boolean {
            for (let kind = 0; kind < ParsingContext.Count; kind++) {
                if (parsingContext & (1 << kind)) {    // `Line 2`
                    if (isListElement(kind, /*inErrorRecovery*/ true) || isListTerminator(kind)) {
                        return true;
                    }
                }
            }
            return false;
        }
```
From the for-loop, it seems the enum is not used as flag, but `Line 1` would make most condition out of range, and let switch clause loss of use.
`Line 2` is also strange, it seems some enum kind are very special in the condition and only take them as parameter (I means 1Ôºå2,4,8,16). 

I feel someone confused the types, sometimes he treats the enum as flags and sometimes not.

Feel free to close this if it is intended. And it would be sweet to give a simple reason.

If it is really a bug, I would be glad to fix it. (or maybe it is more proper to be fixed by core team?)
author: ShuiRuTian

comments.body: The enum gets used both ways. The `switch` there refers to the `parsingContext` parameter that takes a plain `ParsingContext` value, whereas `isInSomeParsingContext` operates on a bitfield. I'm not entirely sure why we didn't just define this as a flags from the get-go, but it's not a bug.
Thanks for the detailed reason, glad to know how it works!

title: TypeScript 4.0 AST > string | null produces Union(StringKeyword, LiteralType) instead of Union(StringKeyword, NullKeyword)
body:
For the following type:

```ts
type Category = {
    name: string | null
}
```

TypeScript 4.0 produces a following AST:

```ts
name > UnionType
                  > StringKeyword
                  > LiteralType
                       > NullKeyword
```

Before 4.0 it was:

```ts
name > UnionType
                  > StringKeyword
                  > NullKeyword
```

Just want to make sure new AST is correct before applying changes in my code.
author: pleerock

comments.body: This is the intended categorization since `null` is a literal value at runtime (where as `string` is only a reserved keyword)

title: TypeScript package is transpiled to ES5 on npm
body:
## Search Terms
npm, compiler
<!-- List of keywords you searched for before creating this issue. Write them down here so that others can find this suggestion more easily -->

## Suggestion
Is there any reason the TypeScript package itself is transpiled down to ES5 on npm? The last version of Node.js without ES2015 support was released five years ago. Right now the `typescript` package is sitting at around 50MB on npm. I imagine that switching to an ES2015 build or above would also slightly improve the performance.
author: alex-kinokon

comments.body:
The TS package gets rolled in to other environments like the Visual Studio Online editor that functions in older runtimes. People are also running TS in some strange-ish environments where ES2015 isn't available.

We've tested these things and in general perf/size wins from not downleveling are either very small or even negative; there's not really any downside to targeting older runtimes.
@RyanCavanaugh Thanks for the answer!

title: Compiler API: getConstantValue() can't get a real value from enum's PropertyAccessExpression
body:
<!-- Please try to reproduce the issue with `typescript@next`. It may have already been fixed. -->
**TypeScript Version:**  3.5.3

<!-- Search terms you tried before logging this (so others can find this issue more easily) -->
**Search Terms:**

Compiler API, getConstantValue, PropertyAccessExpression

**Code**

```ts
import * as ts from "typescript";


let program = ts.createProgram(['/src/sandbox/test.ts'], {});
let checker = program.getTypeChecker();

let source = program.getSourceFile('/src/sandbox/test.ts')!;

source.forEachChild(node => {
  switch (node.kind) {
    case ts.SyntaxKind.EnumDeclaration:
      (() => {
        const real = node as ts.EnumDeclaration;
        real.members.forEach(item => {
          console.log(item.name.getText(), checker.getConstantValue(item))
        })
      })()
      break;
    case ts.SyntaxKind.ExpressionStatement:
      (() => {
        const a = node as ts.ExpressionStatement;
        const real = a.expression as ts.PropertyAccessExpression;
        console.log(checker.getConstantValue(real)) // ------------------------> Undefined
      })()
      break
  }
});
```

The '/src/sandbox/test.ts':
```ts
enum Test {
    A = 100,
    B,
}

Test.A;
```

**Expected behavior:**

Tell me `100`

**Actual behavior:**

Returns `undefined`
author: mohanson

comments.body:
getConstantValue doesn't follow references back to their declaration. You have to do that yourself by looking at the symbol's declaration. Something like

`checker.getConstantValue(checker.getSymbolAtLocation(real))`
Got it!

title: Support 'as const' together with type restriction
author: KnutRyagerInmeta

comments.body: Your type `MyType` clearly says that `name` is a mutable property. If you want it read-only, then you can just use `Readonly<MyType>`.

Helper function to the rescue!

```ts
type MyType = { name: string };
const asMyType = <T extends MyType>(x: T) => x; // helper function
const x = asMyType({ name: "test" } as const); // üòÉ
```

@jcalz this does the trick.

@MartinJohns readonly was not originally of my concern, but emerged with 'as const'. Seems with jcalz's solution readony does not emerge. Now a single string literal type should be readonly by implication though... well you are allowed to overwrite with the same string I guess.

@KnutRyagerInmeta You mean a string literal type, e.g. `'fixed'` instead of `string`. In that case the same logic applies: Your type `MyType` explicitly says the property `name` can be of **any** string.

With jcalz solution you will have the same issue when you use the wrong type:

    const x: MyType = asMyType({ name: "test" } as const); // x.name is of type string again

But I likely misunderstand you, and you want something like "make sure this object matches SomeType, then make it a const context", in which case jcalz solution is probably the best.

title: Please include that typeRoots is used only for resolving <reference path=""/> tags
body:
I've wasted tons of time and was so frustrated because the typeRoots option wasn't working as I expected. The type definition file could not be found so I looked up the documentation multiple times, googled around, and finally managed to find an answer on github issues stating that it is only for resolving the `/// <reference path=""/>` tag and that I should use the `include` option instead.

The current description for the `typeRoots` option is "List of folders to include type definitions from." and this description is sloppy and misleading. I've seen multiple other users confused and asking the same questions I did. If this description can be updated to be more precise, it would really save a lot of users' time and frustrations.

title: weird type relationship
body:
problem:

```ts
declare function sureNever<_T extends never>(): void;
type NeverDifferent<L, R> = L extends R ? R extends L ? never : 'right does not extend left' : 'left does not extend right';
sureNever<NeverDifferent<'a', 'a'>>(); // works
sureNever<NeverDifferent<{}, {}>>(); // works
sureNever<NeverDifferent<'a' | 'b', 'a' | 'b'>>(); // breaks: Type '"right does not extend left"' does not satisfy the constraint 'never'
```

nasty workaround:

```ts
declare function sureIdentical<L, R>(
    asRight: (left: L) => R,
    asLeft: (right: R) => L,
): void;
sureIdentical<'a' | 'b', 'a'>(x => x, x => x); // breaks as expected
sureIdentical<'a', 'a' | 'b'>(x => x, x => x); // breaks as expected
sureIdentical<'a' | 'b', 'a' | 'b'>(x => x, x => x); // works as expected
```
author: zpdDG4gta8XKpMCd

comments.body:
Conditional type distributivity (yr fav) is what's causing this. This produces the behavior desired by the example:
```ts
type NeverDifferent<L, R> = [L] extends [R] ? R extends L ? never : 'right does not extend left' : 'left does not extend right';
```
that pesky distributivity again, ok, noted

title: allow type morphing
body:
considering a certain (better constrained generic) type in current TS, there is no easy way to:

- add/replace/remove a property
- add/replace/remove a parameter

it makes it extremely hard to get the resulting types out of builders

```ts
// what is the type of result?
const result = building<A>().addProp<string>('x').replaceProp<number>('y').removeProp('z');
```

sure you can do:
```ts
type Result = typeof result;
```

but only if there are **no functions** and **no generics involved**

```ts
function make<X, Y>() {
     const result = building<A>().addProp<X>('x').replaceProp<Y>('y').removeProp('z');
     return result;
}
type Result<X, Y> = typeof make<X, Y>; // <-- dang! now what?
```

without types you **cannot pass stuff around**, so the results of the builders are **not transferable**, so it limits the composability of the code and overall design of the application

it's a super major headache with higher order components in React:

-  they are easy to build, but very hard to type

**so i wish there was something as convenient as builders, but for the _type domain_**

please consider these use cases:

```ts
interface A {
    x: number;
    y: { z: string; };
}
type B = /* some magic here */ A;
```
-------------------
1. type `B` same as `A` but without property `y`
```ts
type B = { x: number; };
```
current answer: 
```ts
type B = Omit<A, 'y'>;
```
-------------------
2. type `B` same as `A` but with property `x` of type `string`
```ts
type B = { x: string; y: string; };
```
current answer: 
```ts
type B = Omit<A, 'x'> | { x: string };
```
-------------------
3. type `B` same as `A` but with property `y.z` removed:
```ts
type B = { x: string; y: {}; };
```
current answer: 
```ts
type B = Omit<A, 'y'> & { y: Omit<A['y'], 'z'> };
```
-------------------
4. type `B` same as `A` but with property `y.z` of type `boolean`
```ts
type B = { x: string; y: { z: boolean; }; };
```
current answer
```ts
type B = Omit<A, 'y'> & { y: Omit<A['y'], 'z'> & { z: boolean; }; };
```
-------------------
... see where i am going?

now...
```ts
interface A {
    m(x: string, y: number): void;
}
type B = /* some magic here */ A;
```
-------------------
5. type `B` same as `A` but with first parameter removed
```ts
type B = { m(y: number): void; };
```
current answer
```
// NOT SURE IF IT IS DOABLE, SOME VERY UGLY CODE
```
-------------------
6. type `B` same as `A` but with first parameter of type `boolean`
```ts
type B = { m(x: boolean, y: number): void; };
```
current answer
```
// SOME VERY UGLY CODE
```
-------------------
7. type `B` same as `A` but with with extra parameter of type `boolean`
```ts
type B = { m(x: string, y: number, z: boolean): void; };
```
current answer
```
// NOT SURE IF IT IS DOABLE, IF IT IS IT WILL BE VERY UGLY
```

-------------------
7. type `B` same as `A` but with with extra parameter of type `boolean` after 1st one
```ts
type B = { m(x: string, z: boolean, y: number): void; };
```
current answer
```
// NOT SURE IF IT IS DOABLE, IF IT IS IT WILL BE VERY UGLY
```
-------------------
...etc
author: zpdDG4gta8XKpMCd

comments.body:
ok, i need to add `w: string, v: boolean` inside `x.y.z` and remove `u` from `x.y`
i am not picking on you, it's a real problem, the solution you are suggesting is hideous when it is taken to the real life situations extent

I'm not sure what you're proposing, then. The primitives are there, and any highly complex operation expressed in terms of smaller primitives is going to look kind of ugly regardless of what order the operands go in. What kind of sugar would be understandable and also meaningfully better?

title: Language Service(?) is abbreviating types too aggressively
body:
I have a project with some pretty complicated types - generics with function signatures as type parameters, themselves returning generic types of all sorts.  I've noticed in using 3.3.3333 with vscode 1.32.3 that my tooltips types are abbreviated in a new way with ellipses throughout.  I understand the intent but these abbreviations are too aggressive.  I'm trying to debug my types and I can't tell whether/where some of the nested type inferences are getting dropped (to `{}` or `any`, for example).

I don't know how to repro this issue because it is specifically related to the size and complexity of the types involved.  Maybe others can contribute anecdotes of this happening with popular libraries?  Or maybe someone with knowledge of the code can call out the culprit more actionably.

I guess that there's some algorithm that assigns weights to the various parts of the type tree and adds ellipses to keep the rendered length under some limit.  Is there a way to tinker with this limit as a user to allow me to see longer or even complete signatures, even if they're a mile long?  Or maybe there's a usability nuance that the weightings aren't accounting for.  All I know is that I'm unable to see the inferred types that I need to see to debug my types.
author: JasonKleban

comments.body:
You can try the `noErrorTruncation` compiler option. Despite the name it seems to also work for quickinfo.

There's a proposal (here or in the VSCode repo) to make quickinfo tooltips interactive, so you can click on the ellipsis to expand it. Unfortunately I cannot find it right now.
`noErrorTruncation` doesn't help. It'll still show the ellipsis.

The `...` is also used for reverse mapped types where we used to incorrectly print `any` (we actually still have strong types for the thing all the way down, the structure just expands potentially forever).

title: API: how to get TypeParameters of inferred higher order function
body:
<!-- Please try to reproduce the issue with `typescript@next`. It may have already been fixed. -->
**TypeScript Version:**  3.4.0-dev.20190309

**Code**

```ts
// from #30215
declare function pipe<A extends any[], B, C>(ab: (...args: A) => B, bc: (b: B) => C): (...args: A) => C;

declare function list<T>(a: T): T[];
declare function box<V>(x: V): { value: V };

const listBox = pipe(list, box);  // <T>(a: T) => { value: T[] }

listBox(1); // <-- want to get TypeParameters here
```

Given a CallExpression, I want to get all type parameters of the resolved signature.
Before higher order function type inference, I could simply use `ts.getEffectiveTypeParameterDeclarations(checker.getResolvedSignature(node).declaration)`.

This doesn't work in the example above, because `signature.declaration` is `(...args: A) => C` which obviously has no declared type parameters.

I noticed there's `signature.typeParameters`, but that seems to always be `undefined` on instantiated signatures.
Using the debugger I could see that `signature.target.typeParameters` contains what I need, but `target` is internal.

Currently I'm trying to work around this by getting the type of `listBox` first and using the uninstantiated signature iff there's only one call signature. Otherwise I fall back to my previous solution because inferred higher order functions currently only work with a single call signature.
Is that the recommended way to solve my problem?
author: ajafff

comments.body:
Doesn't look like there's a way to do it with the available public API. To really get the right answer you'd also need the `.mapper` and then instantiate the type with the provided the mapper.

More details on your use case would be useful if you'd like to see changes in the public API to accommodate some scenario.

title: Get type of variable over the course of lifetime from TypeChecker
body:
Calling `getTypeAtLocation().getFlags()` on  the identifier `b` at its declaration in the following example returns `ts.TypeFlags.Number` however the type (to me) should be `ts.TypeFlags.Number` or `ts.TypeFlags.Any` since it is later reassigned to a variable of unknown type.

```
function a(c) { // c is implicit any
  let b = 1; // getTypeAtLocation(b).getFlags() is ts.TypeFlags.Number
  b = c; // getTypeAtLocation(b = c).getFlags() is no longer ts.TypeFlags.Number
}
```

Is it possible to get this information at the declaration of `b` or do I need to accumulate this type information myself?
author: eatonphil

comments.body: I'm not totally clear on the intent but if you're asking about the type of `b = c`, that's because the `=` operator always returns the right-hand side.

There isn't an API that's going to give you answer you want there, because TypeScript's inference algorithm doesn't work like that. You'd have to accumulate the RHSes of all assignments yourself to get the `number | string` result.
Got it, thank you!

title: Compiler hangs with no output - how to debug?
body:
**TypeScript Version:**  3.4.0-dev.20190228

I have a project that contains references to sub-projects. For some reason, the compiler hangs with no output, and finally crashes with FATAL ERROR: CALL_AND_RETRY_LAST Allocation failed - JavaScript heap out of memory.

I haven't been able to isolate the problem. It is somehow related to importing monocle-ts in sub-project, but it seems very random.

My question is: is there a way to find out what causes the compiler to crash? Can I enable debug output in tsc, or something else?
author: lvanhala

comments.body:
There isn't meaningful debug output generated during phases which typically cause these kinds of crashes.

The best thing to do is to run `node --inspect tsc.js [your commandline]`, attach a debugger, wait until you think it's close to crashing, then break the debugger and capture the call stack along with values of relevant locals. Usually there will be a `node` somewhere in the stack trace that will point you to which line of source is the root cause.

title: [Compiler API] transform import when module is set to commonjs
body:
Hi there,

I'm writing a TS transformer that inline some `import` depending on certain file type. For example:

```
import {foo, bar} from 'static-file'
const baz = foo + bar
// Transform into
const foo = 1, bar = 2
const baz = foo + bar
```

When I set `tsconfig`'s module to `ESNext`, the example above works. However, when the `module` config is `CommonJS`, import `namedBindings` seem to get aliased.

```
import {foo, bar} from 'static-file'
const baz = foo + bar
// Transform into
const foo = 1, bar = 2
const baz = static_file_1.foo + static_file_1.bar
```

I'd love to learn more about the context of why it behaves that way and potentially how to solve my issue.

Thank you so much!

LH
author: longlho

comments.body: ES6 module bindings are "live" - they always observe the value of the property as it exists in the imported module, not just grab the value once at file startup time and then not change again.
gotcha thanks!

title: Typing specification on compile

title: Doc bug in function section.
body:
In the docs, it says

> In playing with the example, you may notice that the TypeScript compiler can figure out the type if you have types on one side of the equation **but not the other**:
> ```
> // myAdd has the full function type
> let myAdd = function(x: number, y: number): number { return  x + y; };
> 
> // The parameters 'x' and 'y' have the type number
> let myAdd: (baseValue: number, increment: number) => number =
>     function(x, y) { return x + y; };
> 
> ```

It seems to me that *"not the other"* is incorrect. I think what is meant to be said is *"not both"*. It seems from the documentation that typescript can infer the type of `myAdd` from the function, or infer the type of the arguments in the function from the type of `myAdd`, but not infer the types of `x` and `y` in isolation of any type declaration.

It may be worth mentioning the reason here too: why it can't infer the types of both -- presumably because the `+` operator is polymorphic.
author: EvanCarroll

comments.body:
If types are present on both sides, then there's nothing left to figure out.

It's like saying in a room full of a dozen people, I can figure out the last name if given a first name, or the first name if given a last name, ... but not both? It's not even clear what that means.

Interesting and compelling example. Perhaps that's the oversight -- I don't read "but not the other" to mean that TypeScript just accepts explicit typing on both sides. For me the wording is just awkward and causes confusion. Consider,

> It's like saying in a room full of a dozen people, I can figure out the name if you provide the first name, or last name **but not the other**.

That's how I read it currently. Perhaps though we could skirt the whole issue by rewording entirely,

> In playing with the example, you may notice that the TypeScript compiler can figure out the types absent from either side, with the types present on the other.

This is a pretty common turn of phrase, I thought.  "There's something on side of the fence, but not the other".  The general meaning is that there are two pigeonholes, but only one has something in it--without specifying which one that is (because it's not relevant).

I'll agree the wording in this case is awkward, though.  This would probably be clearer:
> In playing with the example, you may notice that the TypeScript compiler can figure out the type **even if you only have types on one side of the equation:**

```typescript
(<any>window).MyNamespace = {...((<any>window).MyNamespace || {}), ...MyNamespace};
```

title: LS-Plugin: what to use for filesystem IO
body:
I'm currently writing a LanguageService plugin.
I need read access to the file system and probably a bit of file watching in this plugin. I don't want to use Node's `fs` module directly to allow execution in other environments.
So I looked for existing abstractions to do FileSystem IO. Here's what I found out so far:

`PluginCreateInfo.serverHost`: the host of all hosts, accesses the file system directly
`PluginCreateInfo.project`: uses a CachedDirectoryStructureHost to allow file system reads, doesn't support watching
`PluginCreateInfo.languageServiceHost`: the same as `PluginCreateInfo.project` in the default implementation? with a lot of optional methods so not really pleasant to use

When using `ServerHost` for file watching I need to clean up after myself when my plugin is disposed?

Are the assumptions above correct? Is there some kind of documentation how this all works together (other than looking at the code)?
author: ajafff

comments.body: @sheetalkamat do you know if we have a doc page on how the `host`s for the plugin/server APIs are related?

I dont know if there is documentation around it but `ts.sys` is our FS abstraction. Other hosts like language service or project arent file system implementers. Eg. Project implements languageServiceHost so it doesn't need watch implementation. it internally does watch depending on what kind of languageServiceHost commands take place. (eg. from program watching missing files etc)

Thank you for the insights. I think I'll try to avoid `ts.sys` as the `ServerHost` might use a different means for filesystem access.
My current approach is using `Project` where possible and falling back to `ServerHost` for watching.

title: Classes cannot satisfy Constructor<Itself> bound
body:
<!-- Please try to reproduce the issue with `typescript@next`. It may have already been fixed. -->
**TypeScript Version:**  3.2.0-dev.201xxxxx

<!-- Search terms you tried before logging this (so others can find this issue more easily) -->
**Search Terms:** generics mixin classes interfaces constructor

**Code**

```ts
type Constructor<T> = new(...args: any[]) => T;

interface XInterface {}
function make<T extends Constructor<XInterface>>(Base: T) {
    return class extends Base implements XInterface {}
}

// This is ok.
class X extends make(Function) { }

// But this fails.
class X2 extends make(Function) implements Constructor<XInterface> { }
```

**Expected behavior:** 
Code should compile

**Actual behavior:**
Compiler error: X2 provides no match for signature `new(...args: any[]) => XInterface`


--- 

**Edit 1:**
Looks like even something more basic like 

```ts
class Y implements XInterface, Constructor<XInterface> {}
```

fails to compile. This makes it difficult to chain together a set of mixin extending through another mixin function. 

**Edit 2**

Looks like even the simplest case of

```ts
class Y implements Constructor<Y>
```

fails.

title: Spread operator with one union-typed key gives type error?
author: ziriax

comments.body: When you say `x.id`, you get the type of the `id` field on both `Foo` and `Bar` - so `Identifier<Tag.FOO> | Identifier<Tag.BAR>`. The assignment doesn't retain a dependency relationship on `x`'s type, so what happens is in both of the union elements you spread over, you assign this combined type to both members, causing the problem.

Thanks for clarifying. Coming from C# and C++, this is very peculiar :-) But it does make perfect sense if you look at it this way. 

Thanks, closing this then, since it is by design.

title: Why promise will be unwrapped by dynamic import?
body:
I got mysterious inferred type with dynamic import.In `dynamic import` with `typeof`,Promise will be unwrapped.

```json
{
  "foo": "FOO"
}
```

```typescript
const json = import('./sample.json')
type ImportedJsonType = typeof json
type DynamicImportedJsonType = typeof import('./sample.json')
```

```typescript
// result of infer
type ImportedJsonType = Promise<{ "foo": string }>
type DynamicImportedJsonType = { "foo": string }
```
I would like to know the reasons for this behavior. Best reguards.
author: takefumi-yoshii

comments.body:
`import('./sample.json')` as expression returns a Promise because it executes asynchronously.
`import('./sample.json')` as type is not intended to be the same as the expression counterpart. It's meant to reference a type of another module inline. Since it has no runtime behavior, it doesn't need to result in a Promise-type.
@ajafff Thanks for reply.If there has some discussion at past time,I'd like to know related issues.I would like to still open this one day.

title: API: how to work with fresh type literal or literal type?
body:
With all the type freshness recently added, is there a way to actually use it through the public API?
`ts.TypeFlags.FreshLiteral` is internal, so that's not an option.

Last time I checked none of the `TypeChecker.getType*` methods returned a type with the freshness flag set, even though is should definitely be there.

Is freshness a concept that is not intended for API users to know and care about?
author: ajafff

comments.body:
> Is freshness a concept that is not intended for API users to know and care about?

I want to say this is the answer, however I'll defer to @RyanCavanaugh and @weswigham. Is there any reason you need to know about freshness?

It's intended to be internal. Consumers should just be aware that there can be multiple variants of a literal type with different triple-equals assignability that are still essentially identical types, so generally speaking, using triple equals to check for the presence of a specific type is a bad idea. A relationship like isIdenticalTo or isAssignableTo is almost always more correct.

> Is there any reason you need to know about freshness?

Admittedly there are not many use cases and the one I'm presenting here may not be too useful either:
I have a lint rule to detect useless assertions. Currently I have to ignore assertions with literal types as they are used to prevent widening (remove freshness).

```ts
declare function identity<T>(p: T): T;
identity('foo' as 'foo'); // assertion is not necessary because identity functions make fresh literal type non-widening
const wideningFoo = 'foo';
const nonWideningFoo = wideningFoo as 'foo'; // assertion is necessary to remove freshness

'foo' as 'foo'; // assertion is necessary to remove freshness
nonWideningFoo as 'foo'; // assertion is not necessary on a non-widening type
```

The last case in the above example cannot be detected right now.

> A relationship like isIdenticalTo or isAssignableTo is almost always more correct.

I wish one of these functions was exposed as part of the public API. Currently I can only compare type identity using triple equals or compare the output of `typeToString`

I have another use case: I have a rule to detect useless initializers (in ObjectBindingPattern).
It works by looking at the initializer of the VariableLikeDeclaration and check if the destructured property is optional or allows `undefined`.
Unfortunately the type checker adds `SymbolFlags.Optional` to properties of fresh object literals if the destructuring has a default initializer:

```ts
let {a = '', b = ''} = {a: 1, b: Boolean() ? 'foo' : undefined};
```

In the above example properties `a` and `b` are both marked as optional (even though they will always be present). I could simply ignore that flag if I knew that I'm dealing with a fresh object literal. But there's no way for me to find out that the containing type is a fresh object literal (besides looking at the AST).

title: Infer Interfaces from types
body:
<!-- üö® STOP üö® ùó¶ùóßùó¢ùó£ üö® ùë∫ùëªùë∂ùë∑ üö®

Half of all issues filed here are duplicates, answered in the FAQ, or not appropriate for the bug tracker. Please read the FAQ first, especially the "Common Feature Requests" section.

-->

## Search Terms

infer interfaces types automatic generate mock

## Suggestion

Infer interfaces from public members of types.
`<TypeName>.Interface` would be understood as an interface which requires all public members of **TypeName** to be implemented.

## Use Cases

The majority of interfaces I have in my projects are for testing purpose, to allow mocking out related modules. Any signature change needs to happen always in 3 places (interface, real implementation and mock) what is bothersome.

That would remove the need of writing explicitly this kind of interface.

## Examples

```ts
// Given a type:
class Foo {
     public foo(): string {
        return "I am foo";
    }
}

// This would be a mock implementation:
class MockFoo1 implements Foo.Interface {
     public foo(): string {
        return "mockresult";
    }
}

// This would complain of missing foo function:
class MockFoo2 implements Foo.Interface {
     public bar(): string {
        return "I am foo";
    }
}

// Happy Assignments:
const foo: Foo.interface = new Foo();
const mockFoo1: Foo.interface = new MockFoo1();
```

## Checklist

My suggestion meets these guidelines:
* [X] This wouldn't be a breaking change in existing TypeScript / JavaScript code
* [X] This wouldn't change the runtime behavior of existing JavaScript code
* [X] This could be implemented without emitting different JS based on the types of the expressions
* [X] This isn't a runtime feature (e.g. new expression-level syntax)

comments.body:

```ts
class MockFoo1 implements Foo {
```
and get the behavior you've described. No new syntax needed

title: Support typeguards for class members
author: sigmasoldi3r

comments.body:
Yes, it can be used as a solution and works fine (Thanks for the answer).

However, the field cannot be private:
```
TS2546: Property 'value' has conflicting declarations and is inaccessible in type 'Optional & { value: any; }'.
```

(But with public field works, which is better than passing it again)

There's no point to provide a public type guard on a private member, though - if you're inside the class, you can already directly test against it; if you're outside the class, the fact that the private field isn't null doesn't change what you can do with the class instance.

title: Import a side-effects only module and generate ES6 style module importing syntax.
body:
<!-- üö® STOP üö® ùó¶ùóßùó¢ùó£ üö® ùë∫ùëªùë∂ùë∑ üö®

Half of all issues filed here are duplicates, answered in the FAQ, or not appropriate for the bug tracker. Please read the FAQ first, especially the "Common Feature Requests" section.

-->

## Search Terms

module; import; side-effects; es6 module

## Suggestion

By now, tsc keeps the importing statement unchanged when compiling ts file to ES6 js.
Given a module, named ModuleA, its contents seem like:
```js
(function(){
  var ModuleA = {
    /* members */
  };
})();
```
It also has a .d.ts file defined well.
Next, in a ts file, we want to import it:
```ts
  import * as ModuleA from "./Module";

  let v = new ModuleA.ClassFoo();
```
In the meantime, the intelligense(of Visual studio code) works well when coding.
But when I compile it(target ES6, module-style ES6) and run. The browser hints that "ClassFoo is not a constructor."

To fix it, I change the importing statement in *ts* file as:
```ts
  import "./Module"
```
It got compile errors(and the intelligense didn't work anymore) but it can work in browser.

## Use Cases

* Want generating ES6 codes;
* Use a non-ES6 style library, no export, but have corresponding .d.ts definitions.

## Examples

I met this problem when use library **konva** for 2D painting.

Reference codes:

index.html
``` html
<script type="module">
  import "./main.js";
  main();
</script>
```

main.ts
```ts
import "./node_modules/konva/konva.js";
function main()
{
  let stage = new Konva.Stage();
}
```

The konva library is install from npm.

## Checklist

title: Define an enum as the cartesian product of two enums. Is it possible?

Hi,
I was wondering if the type system allows to achieve the following.

Say I have two enums, `ReportType` and `AggregateBy`:

```
enum ReportType = {
  ContentSummary,
  VideoUsage
}

enum AggregateBy {
   Day,
   Month
}
```
I'd like to be able to create a third enum obtained as the cartesian product of those two.
The result would be:

```
{
   ContentSummaryDay
   ContentSummaryMonth,
   VideoUsageDay,
```

author: alexandro81

comments.body: Not automatically, but you could use `interface ReportAndAggregate { report: ReportType; aggregate: AggregateBy; }`, which is sometimes called a "product type" and whose set of possible values is the cartesian product of those two enums.

Yeah, I was thinking about something more generic, maybe using mapped types to define a `Product` type alias that takes 2 type parameters and builds a new type that is indeed the cartesian product of the values of the input types.
`interface Product<T, U> { first: T, second: U }`, or just `[T, U]`, would work for that, but I think it's less readable than using a named interface.

title: Attach type parameter to (non-method) function-valued property in object type
body:
## Search Terms
generic in object key type alias parameter

## Suggestion

My apologies if this has been suggested before or if there's already a way to do it that I'm not aware of... I wasn't exactly sure how to search for this issue. But, basically, here's the situation:

Suppose I have an interface/object type like:

```ts
interface X {
  applyPreMiddleware<T extends SomeType = SomeType>(it: T, opts: B): Promise<T | undefined>
  applyPostMiddleware<T extends SomeTypePostProcessing = SomeTypePostProcessing>(it: T, opts: B): Promise<T | undefined>
}

// Note: SomeTypePostProcessing extends SomeType
```

The `applyPreMiddleware` and `applyPostMiddleware` accept an object and apply registered middleware functions for objects of that type. Now, suppose I want to pull out the common signature, say, to use for an underlying function. Something like: 

```ts
type applyMiddleware<T extends SomeType = SomeType> = 
  (it: T, opts: B) => Promise<T | undefined>
```

What I'd like is a way to use this common type to define the `interface X` above, so I don't have to repeat the common bits. Something like:

```ts
interface X {
  applyPreMiddleware<T extends SomeType = SomeType>: applyMiddleware<T>;
  applyPostMiddleware<T extends SomeTypePostProcessing = SomeTypePostProcessing>: applyMiddleware<T>;
}
```

Basically, I'm trying to reference the type alias instead of putting the function signature inline. When I try the above, though, I get a syntax error.

Note: the generic parameter has to be on the methods, not the interface, because the value for `T` can be different each time each method is called.

## Checklist

My suggestion meets these guidelines:
* [x] This wouldn't be a breaking change in existing TypeScript / JavaScript code
* [x] This wouldn't change the runtime behavior of existing JavaScript code
* [x] This could be implemented without emitting different JS based on the types of the expressions
* [x] This isn't a runtime feature (e.g. new expression-level syntax)

title: Recursive mapped type inference not working as expected
author: massimonewsuk

comments.body: Note: since `Node` has all-optional properties, everything extends it, so the conditional types will always use the true branch. Could you update your example to avoid that pitfall?
@andy-ms Thanks, that's cleared things up a bit... it seems that the `Array` is a special case where things aren't quite working as expected... the examples with `Node` all work fine now

It looks like you can fix that by changing `T[P] extends Array<infer U>` to `T[P] extends Array<infer U> | undefined` -- since `T[P]` still contains `undefined` even though you removed optionality from the property.

You're right - I could have sworn I tried that and it never helped.

I've updated my original code example to what I actually wanted to achieve.

It seems to work fine in 2.9.1 so I'm closing the issue. Sorry for taking your time!

Some things I noticed:
* In the above example, it looks like `NormalFields` can be removed without affecting the erroring examples.
* `EagerLoadedRelations` is a `Pick`. `Pick` doesn't have any deep effects, it just picks certain fails. `Mandatory` also doesn't work deeply, so it will only have an effect on first-level fields, not `eagerOrder.customer.bestFriend`.
* The type of values in the first argument to `PropertiesWithoutNevers` only matters to the extent that it extends `TEntity` or not. You can even see when hovering over `eagerOrder` (after removing `NormalFields`) that it's just `var eagerOrder: Pick<Mandatory<Order>, "customer" | "lineItems">`.

title: static return might fail with switch statement
author: ORESoftware

comments.body: You probably just need `--strictNullChecks` enabled.
Or alternatively `--noImplicitReturns`. Enabling `--strictNullChecks` is often very difficult to add in old code bases, but `--noImplicitReturns` is a no-brainer.
@andy-ms yeah that's fine, I guess I would expect the default behavior to always catch this one tho?

The default behaviour is to align with JavaScript. If a function returns "nothing", it implicitly returns `undefined`. That is what is happening here. And with `strictNullChecks` disabled, the value of `undefined` is compatible with the type `Promise<any>`, the value is compatible with **any** type.

`strictNullChecks` will change the semantics of `undefined` from a mere *value* to a *type*, so the value `undefined` will be of the type `undefined`, which is not compatible with `Promise<any>` anymore. You will get an error.

`noImplicitReturns` will enforce what the name implies: A method may not have an implicit return value. That means you have to explicitly write `return undefined;`.

ok understood, to move this in a more productive direction, is there a way to never allow null/undefined in the place of a defined value? In Java, all those NullPointerException's are caused by allowing null to exist in far too many places.

Returning null from a function/method instead of an array or Promise, or anything, it's just crazy imo.
Yes... That is pretty much what `strictNullChecks` is for. And related to that the `strictPropertyInitialization` feature (works only together with `strictNullChecks`.
@MartinJohns  thanks for the info...I still think `strictNullChecks` should be the default behavior, and that users should have to specifically set it to false, but nbd I guess

title: Allow narrowing generic parameters in conditional types
author: SimonMeskens

comments.body:
So in `Test2`, you set `U` to default to `R`, but there are no constraints on it saying it *must* be `R`. The `=` basically offers no assistance here.

I'm less sure what's going on with `Test3`. It seems like that should be looking at `Lambda2<string>` which is `() => string` so `V` should be `string`.

But in both `Test2` and `Test3` we see `() => number` matching with `<U>() => infer V`, which means that conditional types are _not_ picky about generic parameters in the `extends` clauses of function types.

Ultimately, this seems like it should be implemented with higher-kinded types, which is a **very** long-time request: #1213 

...which I see you are fully aware of, being the author of a step forward on that... nevermind me.

Yeah, this issue came out of experiments with HKTs. If I could get either Test2 or Test3 into the language, we would get proper type level pattern matching, which allows us to do lots of cool things, one of which is improving inference for HKTs, but also generic function application, abstract type constructors, etc.
@ahejlsberg I think this one is in your domain?
@mhegazy This isn't a question but a suggestion

The typescript type system is structural. so type parameters need to have a manifestation to be picked up by inference. i.e. used in a parameter type or in a return type for a function. if inference could not find any candidates, the upper bound is returned, which is `{}`.

In the case of `T4`, the compiler is trying to infer for `V` from `Lambda2`, it looks at the param list, to find any candidates for `T` and none are found, so `T` goes to `{}`, then instantiating `Lambda2` with `T = {}` gets us a return type of `{}[]` that is then used to as the inference for `V`.  same process happens in `T6`.

I think I understand now why my suggestion is naive. The example above is just a bug.

Conditionals actually do something like this:
```ts
type Conditional<T extends <U extends "test">(a: U) => S, S = ReturnType<T>> = S;

type T = Conditional<Lambda2>;
```

Except they infer what S is above. So what would be necessary instead is for a proposal orthogonal to conditional types, like type level function application.

title: Suggestion: Expose internals of File Watching beyond simple notification
body:
I am building a framework that tightly couples with Typescript, and it would be useful to be able to tap into the File watcher API.

Currently that functionality culminates in the public API of 

`ts.sys.watchDirectory(directory, callback?:(file:string)=>void, recursive?: boolean):FileWatcher`
`ts.sys.watchFile(file, callback?:(file:string)=>void, pollingInterval?: number):FileWatcher`, 

where `FileWatcher` is 
```
interface FileWatcher {
   close():void;
}
```
The API is very limited compared to the actual underlying functionality, especially given that `watchDirectory` does not indicate if the change is an add, remove or delete.

There are other libraries that do this, with `chokidar` being the forerunner with flexibility and configuration.  Unfortunately `chokidar` weighs in at a very heavy footprint (235 dependencies) due to all the various use cases that they support.
author: arciisine

comments.body:
The file watcher APIs are mainly for our watch scenarios in --watch and in tsserver. they are not intended to be general watch APIs really, and we have no plans to support them as such. 
Can elaborate on what options/additions you need and how/if they tie into the TS main scenarios?

My primary motivator for reaching out, is that it seems like what is currently internal, might work just as well, if not better, for quite a few people. This would be true regardless of whether or not they are using TypeScript.

With respect to the internal nature of the APIs, I think we are in agreement.  Exposing them as is, really doesn't fit in line with the project's goals apart form providing additional tooling.  Though I would say that I somewhat feel the same way about the existing `ts.sys.watchDirectory`.  

Ultimately, I'm thinking what may be best is for me to just repackage the current set of internal APIs (or some approximation there of) as a separate lib and use that.

title: Returning a Proxy from a class does not infer and can‚Äôt be typed
author: mattapperson

comments.body:
First: Try turning on `--noImplicitAny` -- `constructor(adapter)` implicitly makes `adapter: any`, so there's no way to perform type inference on `new Foo`.

Second, we don't support returning a different type from a constructor, that is, `new Foo()` must return a `Foo`. It seems like you want `new Foo(new SomeOtherClass())` to return an object with the interface of `SomeOtherClass`. It might be better to write this as a `function createProxy<T>(value: T): T` instead of as a class.
Automatically closing this issue for housekeeping purposes. The issue labels indicate that it is unactionable at the moment or has already been addressed.

title: PathIn<T> type just like Partial<T> type for deep field path in a object.
author: AmitDigga

comments.body:
`Partial` is built-in for convenience, but it's trivial to implement yourself. It doesn't have any special or hard-coded rules. So you could, in theory, produce your `PathIn` type yourself.

However, there isn't currently any way to modify tuples as types. So you can write a type that finds `['engine']`, and notices that `Car['engine']` is an object, and then recurses and finds `['name']` (well, at least an interface that does that; see below), but no way to join `['engine']` and `['name']` to be `['engine', 'name']`.

But if you were willing to accept other structures for representing this path, that wouldn't be a problem. For example, a linked list would be easy enough to do.

The problem then is that Typescript does not support types that circularly reference themselves. Classes and interfaces can do it, and that's the recommended workaround, but a single interface cannot somehow be a union of anything. Types support distribution across a union, which you need for this.

Given the advent of conditional types, perhaps the eager resolution of types, and therefore their inability to handle circular references, should be revisited.
Automatically closing this issue for housekeeping purposes. The issue labels indicate that it is unactionable at the moment or has already been addressed.

title: One type signature overrides another when undesirable
author: pleerock

comments.body: If you don't want them to have the same keys, why did you write `actions: { [P in keyof PROPS]?: string },`? `actions: object` would fix the compile error.

but it does not provide a type-safety, right? I want first to be some properties of T and second to be some other (or same) properties of T. Just like in first working example, looks like the second is a bit complexier and it does not work.

Well, a bigger problem is that we can't properly infer the type `PROPS` if all we have are its keys. The best you could do is something like this:
```ts
declare function f<PropKeys extends string, ActionKeys extends string>(
    props: { [P in PropKeys]: string },
    actions: { [P in ActionKeys]: string },
): { [K in PropKeys | ActionKeys]: {} };
const o = f({ a: "" }, { m: "" }); // Type is `{ a: {}, m: {} }`
```
It's not possible to infer `PROPS` if the parameters only use its keys. You'll need explicit type arguments in that case.
Can you please explain why its not a bug? When working with this code user feels it like a bug even if you prove that its not a bug, btw.

Type inference can only do so much. If you only use the keys of a type, how is it supposed to infer what that type is? If you have `function f<T>(keys: ReadonlyArray<keyof T>): T` and call `f(["x", "y"])`, what should the return type be?
I understand what you mean, when you are talking about return type do you mean a `: Component<PROPS>` part in my example?

Well, type inference doesn't usually look at the return type, but I am pointing out that the parameter is:
```ts
options: {
    props: { [P in keyof PROPS]?: string },
    actions: { [P in keyof PROPS]?: string },
})
```
The only time `PROPS` appears is in `keyof PROPS`, so there's no way to infer the *values* of `PROPS` by looking at the arguments to a function call.
