title: Difficulties with building a library for distributing
body:
I'm trying to compile a lib for distributing. I want my npm package with the library has the following structure:
```
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄdist
‚îÇ     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄlib/*.js + *.d.ts + *.js.map
‚îÇ     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄmodules/*.js + *.d.ts
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄsrc
‚îÇ     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄlib/*.ts
‚îÇ     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄmodules/*.ts
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄtsconfig.json
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄpackage.json
```
Inside `dist` I want runtime (*.js) script, declaration files for compiling user apps (*.d.ts) and source maps (*.js.map) for debugging that point to sources inside *.ts.
It seems legit structure, nothing fancy. 

I staged all source files into `dist/src` folder. The folder `dist` contains `package.json`, `tsconfig.json` - it's root for npm package that will be published.   

There're two strategies:
1. compile with `-d` inside `dist/src` then rename it to `dist/dist` and move *.ts from it into `dist/src`
2. compile with `-d` and `--outDir dist/dist` options

It turns out that both approaches have problems and don't allow to create a working package.

1. If I compile with `-d` inside `dist/src` then source maps (*.js.map) will have local links (`"file":"file.js", "sourceRoot":"","sources":["file.ts"]`). That means that if I move `*.ts` later from that folder it'll break source mapping for the lib in runtime. It seems that `sourceRoot` option could solve that issue - but it doesn't work as expected - see #23180 (TL;DR: I I set it that tsc put local absolute file paths inside *.js.map).
2. If I compile with `-d` and redirecting into other folder via `--outDir` then another issue arises: if a ts-file has a reference to a declaration besides it (`.d.ts`) then that reference will be changed in output folder.
For example, in `dist/src` I have `file.ts` with a reference to `.stud.d.ts`:
```ts
/// <reference path="./.stubs.d.ts" />
```
after compilation with `-d --outDir ./dist/dist` we'll have `dist/dist/file.d.ts` with the following reference:
```ts
/// <reference path="../src/lib/.stubs.d.ts" />
```
Oh my. This is a problem as I can't copy all *.d.ts from `dist/src` to `dist/dist` because such references become invalid. You may ask me why should I copy `*.d.ts` from `src` to `dist`. Well `dist/dist` should complete distributive and it should work without `dist/src` (which is optional and can be even removed in some cases)

So I can't understand how it suppose to work. How is it meant libraries should be built for distributing?
author: evil-shrike

comments.body:
I do not think the first approach is ideal. as you said it messes up your source maps, though you should know about `--sourceRoot` for these cases.

The second is what i would recommend. to have a recommendation on the .d.ts issue, i need to know what are these .d.ts files represent? are they your code? external dependencies? are they from npm?
also why are you using `/// <references` to start with?

> yes, but as I noted --sourceRoot puts local absolute path into js.map that make then useless

that seems like a bug in tsconfig.json parsing. we should fix that. on the command-line it should be used verbatim, you can also use `file:///./src` to avoid it being resolved.

Do I understand correctly that you are suggesting remove all `/// <reference>` imports from all my *.ts/*.d.ts and put all of them into a single d.ts file, right?
It's far from ideal solution for me. As the lib is modular and every module contains its own references.
And anyway that "entrypoint" should be imported somewhere and at that place its path in reference will be changed on compiling.

It's not clear why tsc can't copy referenced .d.ts into outDir with other created d.ts. If a script imports d.ts via `///<reference>` that means it's needed, so why not to copy it along?

So .d.ts files are not considered sources. the compiler does not generate output for them. think of all your `@types` packages for instance.. 
The compiler does not copy references either.. again think of all your `@types\node` package, you do not want its contents copied to your dist folder just cause you used `require`.
Triple-slash -reference tags are pointers to existing files to include in your compilation, that is all.. we had them before `tsconfig.json` was introduced. it is similar to adding the .d.ts file in the `include` section of your tsconfig.json..
The only difference is that the compiler traffics it to the output, and thus it ensures that it writes your triple-slash-reference tags correctly to output.., consider use case where you have multiple components with a shared folder with .d.ts files. you want the output to still point to the correct shared folder after it is moved.
Looks to me that the best option here is to have your .d.ts files in your dist folder.. e.g. `dist\globals\fileA.d.ts` and reference this in your sources, the compiler will rewrite them in the output to have the correct paths.

For the record.
I abandoned both approaches (`--sourceRoot` and `--outDir`). In the end I just compile everything in-place (in staged folder /dist/dist) where I get *.js, *.ts, *.d.ts, *.js.map then just move *.ts and *.js.map into sibling folder structure /dist/src. So the release package contains:
```
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄdist
‚îÇ     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄlib/*.js + *.d.ts
‚îÇ     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄmodules/*.js + *.d.ts
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄsrc
‚îÇ     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄlib/*.ts + *.d.ts + *.js.map
‚îÇ     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄmodules/*.ts + *.d.ts + *.js.map
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄtsconfig.json
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄpackage.json
```

Inside *.js I have local sourcemap references (like `//# sourceMappingURL=file1.js.map`). So if the lib's users want to debug TS they'll need to copy *.ts and *.js.map from `/src` subtree into server's "wwwroot".

title: Union type in JSX IntrinsicElements seems like a bug
author: mikelnrd

comments.body: Union types are **or**, but not **xor**. **or** means **any** of the types is provided. If all are provided it's fine. **xor** means **one** of the types is provided, not more. Currently it's not directly supported to have a **xor** union type beyond having a discriminated union. See also #14094.
Makes sense, thanks for the quick reply.

title: String Based Enum - Reverse Mapping Problem
author: kannanwisen

comments.body:
String enums has no reverse mapping. Is by design.

See last part of entry post of #15486.
Thanks for your information

@RyanCavanaugh Hi! Could you please explain, why the TS team insists on string enums not having reverse mapping functionality? I have found lots of discussions about it but did not find the rationale behind the decision. Thanks a lot! Cheers, Marcel

If we provided the reverse map automatically (which, by the way, is not necessarily non-ambiguous!), then you'd have no way to distinguish keys from values unless there was a completely separate object created at runtime. It is trivial to write a function that constructs the reverse map if you want it; our goal is to emit as little code as possible so it makes sense to just emit the data you *need* (to keep code size down) and let you construct the reverse map on an as-needed basis.
@RyanCavanaugh That makes sense. Thanks a lot for the explanation! :-)

title: Export `with` as a property within declaration file
body:
I got a CommonJS module that exports a function by default. The function has a property named `with`, which is a reserved word in JavaScript. JavaScript allows this kind of usage (`with` as a property name), but unfortunately, I can't get it working in TS declaration file.

## Code
**a.js**
```javascript
module.exports = () => 1;
module.exports.with = (n: number) => 1 + n;
```

**a.d.ts**
```ts
export = GetNumber;

declare function GetNumber(): number;

declare namespace GetNumber {
	export function with(n: number): number;
}
```

**b.ts**
```ts
import * as getNumber from './a';

console.log(getNumber()); // => 1
console.log(getNumber.with(2)); // => 3
```

title: how to user typescript genericity  like the C#
author: gkjolin

comments.body: In typescript. there is no new T(). how could I do this?

JavaScript has a different execution model than C#. In particular, there are no threads. So patterns you used in C# may not be applicable any more. You may want to study up on the JavaScript language to learn the different ways things are done.
In this case, instead of using the singleton pattern to expose a value, you can just export it as a value like so:

**definition.ts**
```ts
export const myValue = { /*...object contents here...*/ };
```
**user.ts**
```ts
import { myObject } from "./definition";
```
Please do not use our issue tracker for questions in the future, as StackOveflow is a more well-suited venue.

title: Javascript Maps are treated as arrays under spread operation
body:
<!-- Please try to reproduce the issue with `typescript@next`. It may have already been fixed. -->
**TypeScript Version:**

Tested with version typescript@2.7.0-dev.20180113 and latest 2.6.2:

```typescript
const a = new Map<number, number>();
a.set(0, 0);
a.set(1, 1);

const b = new Map<number, number>();
b.set(2, 2);
b.set(3, 3);

const c = [...a, ...b]; // Type 'Map<number, number>' is not an array type.
```

Running `tsc` on the above code also produces:

```javascript
var a = new Map();
a.set(0, 0);
a.set(1, 1);
var b = new Map();
b.set(2, 2);
b.set(3, 3);
var c = a.concat(b);
```

**Expected behavior:**

Maps under spread operator are treated like Maps.

**Actual behavior:**

Maps are treated as arrays.
author: alexluecke

comments.body:
Since you get a type error (`Type 'Map<number, number>' is not an array type.`) you cannot expect valid transpiled code.
Also note that you cannot spread Maps without `target` >= ES6 or `--downlevelIteration` enabled.
`tsc file.ts --lib es2015 --downlevelIteration` and `tsc file.ts --lib es6 --downlevelIteration` produces correct output. Closing.

author: maxkoretskyi

comments.body: @yortus, thanks a lot, works this way. Can you elaborate a bit, why is `declare global` required?

Because TypeScript is assuming you are in a module, likely because of the way you have your `tsconfig.json` configured (or the way you are compiling via `tsc`).  It therefore interfaces by default are scoped locally, instead of globally.  `declare global` indicates you are a module attempting to modify the global interfaces.

title: tsc copy filed not included it's parent dir after compiled with setting other dir exclued in tsconfig.json
body:
`tsc 2.6.2`. there is source dir tree:

```
src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ client
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ client.tsx
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ server
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ actions
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.ts
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ shared
```

where `tsconfig.json` settings:
```json
{
...,
"outDir": "dist",
"exclude": [
    "./src/shared/**/*",
    "./src/client/**/*",
    "./src/server/*.tsx",
    "./src/server/**/*.tsx",
],
"include": [
    "./src/**/*"
  ]
}
```

exec `tsc -p tsconfig.json`, expected `dist dir tree`:
```
src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ server
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ actions
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.ts
```

in factÔºåit output:
```
dist
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.js
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.js.map
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ actions
```

but,  this's `tsconfig.json` is okay:
```json 
{
...,
"outDir": "dist",
"exclude": [
    "./src/shared/**/*",
],
"include": [
    "./src/**/*"
  ]
}
```

the output `dist dir  tree`:
```
dist
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ client
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ server
```

so, i am confused. that is a bug ?üò∑üò∑üò∑

Thanks.
author: Phinome

comments.body:
Seems like a duplicate of #16563.
Normally we will find the common root directory of all the files that were included -- so if you only include files in `src/server` and compile to `dist`, we'll compile from `src/server` to `dist` and not add a `server` directory.
As mentioned in that issue, you can override this behavior by setting an explicit `"rootDir": "src"` in your `"compilerOptions"` in `tsconfig.json`.
Thanks.

title: escapedText property missing on LeftHandSideExpression interface!
author: chandu0101

comments.body:
Not all `LeftHandSideExpression`s have `escapedText` -- only `Identifier`s do. `adder.add(1, 2)` wouldn't have `escapedText` in its `expression`, because it's a `PropertyAccessExpression`.
Besides, `escapedText` is internal and public users should use `text` instead.

title: Cannot use index signature of default export from wildcard module
author: UselessPickles

comments.body:
That is because, on your declaration, you were very specific that the only export is a `default` export. There is no index signature on ES Module exports.

You need to change your import from `import * as jsonData from` into `import jsonData from`.
Alternatively, use `export =` instead of `export default`, and `import jsonData = require("someFile.json")`.

Thanks for the responses. It seems so obvious now that the way I'm importing `*`, but exporting a single default, is inconsistent.

But can anyone explain why my `jsonData` import in my example seems to have an identity crisis? Why does the compiler believe it *is* of type JSONObject (which has an index signature), but that it also does *not* have an index signature because of the way it was imported? In every other way that I use `jsonData`, it works as type JSONObject... as long as I don't try to use the index operator.

Regardless of the fact that I was doing it wrong, it still seems like there's an inconsistency in the behavior of my example.

The compiler doesn't actually believe that `jsonData` is of type `JSONObject`. If you write `const x = jsonData;` and hover over `x` you'll see it says `typeof jsonData`. If you try writing `jsonData.` you'll only get completions for `default`.
It is *assignable* to a `JSONObject` variable though, because the type `{ default: JSONObject }` is assignable to `JSONObject`, since every property value in that type is a `JSONValue`.

Part of my confusion was that my initial setup was working correctly at runtime. Now I understand that it's because the style of my import matched the structure of the actual module that was being generated by webpack. It was only my TS declaration that didn't match, and was causing compile-time confusion under certain conditions. 

The fact that the incorrect TS declaration of the module combined with my import style to produce something that was *assignable* to JSONObject (unfortunate coincidence) was an additional red herring. The end result was that it seemed to "mostly work", unless I tried to directly use the import as a JSONObject.

title: Unable to use loop indexers with union index signatures in strict mode
body:
<!-- BUGS: Please use this template. -->

<!-- Please try to reproduce the issue with `typescript@next`. It may have already been fixed. -->
**TypeScript Version:**  2.7.0-dev.20171123

**Code**

```ts
type Union = 'A' | 'B';
const test: {[key in Union]: string} = {A: 'a', B: 'b'};
for(const key in test) {
	test[key] = test[key] + 'a';
}
```

**Expected behavior:**
No error.

**Actual behavior:**
```
>tsc test.ts --strict
test.ts(4,2): error TS7017: Element implicitly has an 'any' type because type '{ A: string; B: string; }' has no index signature.
test.ts(4,14): error TS7017: Element implicitly has an 'any' type because type '{ A: string; B: string; }' has no index signature.
```

Sorry if this is an issue already; I couldn't find anything quite like this using the issue search or Google.
Basically I'd expect this to work without an error, as the entire point of using an index signature with a string union is to enforce type constraints, not lose them completely.
I get that this is likely because of the whole "keys are always strings at runtime" thing, but it effectively makes any object with a `[key in T]: V` constraint un-indexable in strict mode, and indexing is a big part of why you'd use a constraint like that in the first place.
author: code-elf

comments.body:
If it's not intended to be an index signature, then why does it have the same syntax? That's not only confusing, it also makes it impossible to _also_ define an index signature for the type.
Not to mention that the `[key in T]: V` feature was somewhat 'advertised' as making more narrow index signatures possible, but considering what you just said, something like `[key: StringUnion]: V` seems to still be a missing feature, and one that would be insanely useful in a lot of places, like iterations.

@MayaWolf we're not going to change the syntax at this point, and it's not a bug that the syntax doesn't do what you intuit it should do. I don't see anything actionable here

title: Weird behavior scanning recursive template strings
body:
**TypeScript Version:**  2.7.0-dev.20171115

**Code**

```ts
import * as tsc from "typescript";

const scanner = tsc.createScanner(tsc.ScriptTarget.ES2016, true, tsc.LanguageVariant.Standard);
const str = "`a${`c` + `d${'e'}f`}g`";
scanner.setText(str);

while( scanner.getTextPos() < str.length ) {
    scanner.scan();
    console.log(`${scanner.getTokenText()}\t=> ${scanner.getToken()}`);
}
```

**Expected behavior:**
```diff
    `a${    => 14 //TemplateHead
    `c`     => 13 //NoSubstitutionTemplateLiteral
    +       => 37
    `d${    => 14 //TemplateHead
    'e'     => 9
+   }f`     => 16 //TemplateTail
+   }g`     => 16 //TemplateTail
```

**Actual behavior:**
```diff
    `a${    => 14 //TemplateHead
    `c`     => 13 //NoSubstitutionTemplateLiteral
    +       => 37
    `d${    => 14 //TemplateHead
    'e'     => 9
-   }       => 18 //CloseBraceToken
-   f       => 71 //Identifier
-   `}g`    => 13 //NoSubstitutionTemplateLiteral
```
author: lmcarreiro

comments.body: You can't just blindly call `scan`. See the function `parseTemplateSpan` in `parser.ts` - when encountering a `CloseBraceToken` you need to `reScanTemplateToken`

I thought that the scanner was a state machine that knows its state.

Thanks.

@sandersn Could we infer a more specific `T` in the original example? It seems silly to add `& Holder<T>` when `H` already extends that.

constraints are not inference positions.. they are merely for checking constraints after an inference has occurred. 

Now, the general question is i want to capture a container type "and" the type it contains.. this is doable through one of two ways.. either, you infer the container type, and you access the element type using indexed access type, e.g.:
```ts
function infer<H extends Holder<any>>(holder: H): H['thing'];
```
or through making two inferences using intersection types, e.g.:

```ts
function infer<T, H extends Holder<T>>(holder: Holder<T> & H): T;
```

title: TS2339: Property 'tooltip' does not exist on type '{ label: string; } | { label: string; tooltip: string; }'.
body:
**TypeScript Version:**  typescript@2.6.0-dev.20171014

**Code**

```ts
const cells = [
  { label: '1' },
  { label: '2', tooltip: '2' },
  { label: '3', tooltip: '3' },
  { label: '4' },
  { label: '5' },
  { label: '6' },
]
for (const cell of cells) {
  if (cell.tooltip) console.log(cell.tooltip)
}
```

**Expected behavior:**
That this compiles without error; the error message seems to indicate TS sees a call to cell.tooltip as valid but then forbids it in the second part of the error message.

**Actual behavior:**
```
tt.ts(10,12): error TS2339: Property 'tooltip' does not exist on type '{ label: string; } | { label: string; tooltip: string; }'.
  Property 'tooltip' does not exist on type '{ label: string; }'.
tt.ts(10,38): error TS2339: Property 'tooltip' does not exist on type '{ label: string; } | { label: string; tooltip: string; }'.
  Property 'tooltip' does not exist on type '{ label: string; }'.
```
author: retorquere

comments.body: Looks like a duplicate of #1260. You can get around this with a user-defined type guard or a type-assertion.

I eyed that issue but couldn't make out whether it was the same problem; If it's a dup feel free to close. The suggestions in #1260 do allow compilation, but is this issue planned for a fix in a 2.x release? #1260 has been open for a while.

The easy fix for your problem is a type annotation:
```ts
const cells: {label: string, tooltip?: string} = [
  { label: '1' },
  { label: '2', tooltip: '2' },
  { label: '3', tooltip: '3' },
  { label: '4' },
  { label: '5' },
  { label: '6' },
]
```
Yeah, that's what I settled on in the end.

title: Inconsistent type-check with enum
author: Hachero

comments.body:
The reverse map (from number to string) isn't intended for regular use because it's not guaranteed that any particular *value* has only one *key*, e.g. this is legal:
```ts
enum Foo {
  bar = 1,
  baz = 1
}
Foo[1] // 'baz', not 'bar'
```
For your case I'd recommend using string enums; in general the reverse map for numeric enums should only be used for debugging / error message purposes.

title: number data type implements or not a Number type?
body:
For its language segment I'm writing a detailed tutorial for TypeScript.
But there is one thing that I cannot understand. The data type t implements the data type T?
Or the data type of t compatible with the data type T?
(t === number, string, boolean, symbol, object)
(T === Number, String, Boolean, Symbol, Object)
author: isoftninja

comments.body:
The types `number`, `string`, `boolean`, and `symbol` are the types of values of literals of each of their respective types as well as operators on those types and various conversions.
For example:
```ts
"hello world" // literal -> type of expression is string
var s = "hello world"; // -> type of s is string
```
These types also arise from operations that perform conversions
For example:
```ts
+"12" //  literal (type string) converted via `+`-> expression has type number
```
Another way to write the above is to invoke the JavaScript built in function object `Number`
```ts
Numer("12") // literal (type string) converted by calling `Number`-> expression has type number
```
All of these uses are fine and all produce values of types corresponding to the lowercase variants.

However, where the uppercase variants come into play is when certain JavaScript built in function objects such as the above `Number`, are invoked with `new`.
For example:
```ts
new Number("12") // literal (type string) as ctor arg of `Number`-> expression has type Number
```
These create wrapper objects that have reference identity. They are different types than their literal counterparts.
For example:
```ts
1 === 1
new Number(1) !== 1
new Number(1) !== new Number(1)
```
In typescript, the name of the type of a value created by "newing" a function or class is the name of that function or class.

The uppercase `Number` type exists to represent the objects created by invoking `Number` as a constructor. These objects have different, and in general highly undesirable behavior such as the equality relation shown above.

In practice, the uppercase types should _never_ be used because they represent the values produced by by invoking objects like `Number` as constructors and this should not be done.

Notice how invoking `Number` without `new` results in a `number`, but invoking it with `new` results in a `Number`.

A `Number` is never what you want.

While some might wish to postrationalize this behavior of the JavaScript builtin `Number` by claiming that enabling subclassing was the goal (something still not viable), I personally think that the behavior may be bad legacy that JavaScript inherited from Java.

The same holds for `String`, `Boolean`.

While JavaScript has a built in `Symbol` function object as well, it does not suffer from these problems because it cannot be invoked with `new`. It refers to the `prototype` of all symbol values. These values are of type `symbol`.

`Object` is different in that it refers to the type created by an object literal expression, calling the JavaScript builtin `Object`, and invoking that builtin with `new`. In this case `new` does not change the effect, and produces the same result as normal invocation.

TypeScript introduced the `object` type, to represent the super type or shape, of objects that are _not_ primitives (`string`s, `number`s, `boolean`s, etc) but are not known to have any properties beyond those inherited via `Object.prototype`.

Thanks for the awesome explanation @aluanhaddad.

To add to this, these are also called "wrapper objects", and are used to provide the methods and properties on each primitive.

So for instance, to evaluate `"Hello!".toLowerCase()`, ECMAScript will first try to convert `"Hello!"` to an object (`String`) before fetching a property named `toLowerCase`.

That's why in TypeScript, we use these types to know what methods `string`, `number`, and `boolean` have.

title: Why Record is not obvious behavior? Bug?
author: acopalipsis

comments.body:
I think you might be confused about what `Record<K,T>` is.  It is not an object of type `T`, but an object whose property keys are of type `K` and whose *property values* are of type `T`.  

The object `{name: '', age: 1}` is just an `IPerson`.   It is not a `Record<'name'|'age',IPerson>`.  An actual `Record<'name'|'age',IPerson>` would be an object whose keys `name` and `age`, and whose values are `IPerson`, like: `{name: {name: 'a', age:0}, age: {name: 'b', age:1}}`.

The object `{name: '', age: 1`} *is*, however, a `Record<'name'|'age', string|number>`, since its keys are of type `'name'|'age'` and its values are of type `string|number`.  

Does this clear things up for you?

When you call `record({name: '', age: 1})`, the compiler is trying to match `{name:'', age: 1}` to `Record<K, T>` for some `K` and `T`.  You have written `T === IPerson` above your declaration of `record()`, but that is not possible.  You have passed in an `IPerson`, which is *not* a `Record<K,IPerson>` for any `K`.  It *is* a `Record<'name'|'age', string|number>`, which is what the compiler infers.  

You seem to think that a `Record<K,T>` is itself a `T`, but it is not.   I don't know if I can explain it further without repeating myself.  Rest assured that this is not a bug, but a misunderstanding on your part.  Good luck!

title: about typecript's type assertion
author: JLBear

comments.body:
Type annotations and type assertions do not change the emitted JavaScript. They are solely for conveying information to the compiler. That means that `b` is a `number`on the second to last line of the example above.

Instead of annotating `b` with the _type_ `string`, use the JavaScript runtime global function `String` to convert `a` to a `string` like so
```ts
var a = 12345;
var b = String(a);
console.log(b.length); // 5
```
Note that in the code above, the compiler knows that `a` is of type `number` and that `b` is of type `string` by inferring the types from the initializers `=`. Specifically, it knows the types because `12345` is a value of type `number` and that the `String` function always returns a `string`. Therefore, it is rarely necessary to specify the types of local variables.

You could change the return type to `function foo(): Promise<void> | void`.

title: Type loss when using generic decorators
author: oleg-codaio

comments.body: On another note, if `bar()` is marked private, then the original error returns - it seems that in this case, the decorator is only able to access public properties? My gut feeling is this is a limitation we'd have to deal with.

Just nothing that this `function decorate<T extends Base>(property: keyof T)`  does not have any place to infer `T`, you can not infer a type from a name of one of its properties. and remember decorate is a factory that returns a function that will be used to decorate. so it is equivalent to `decorate(property: keyof Base)`, which means you can only decorate properties that have the same name as ones in `Base`.

So @aluanhaddad's suggestion seems like the correct solution here.

Your explanation makes sense. Though the issue still stands that it doesn't seem currently possible to have decorate properties work off the decorated class. It would be great if there was a way to give "context" to decorator properties as to what exact object they're decorating.

title: Type inference works outside of a function, but not inside of it
author: RafaelSalguero

comments.body:
TypeScript determines function return type at declaration site. That means, `inferTypes` is typed by abstract type variable `T`, not by `typeof data`. An unbound type variable `T` is reduced to `{}`, naturally.

You can just call `paramTypes`, or annotate `inferTypes` in the same way as `paramTypes`.

Is there a reason for that behavior?
Or is this not implemented yet?

The compiler logic is simpler if we only support access to properties that definitely exist.

comments.body:
that is not true. you can have a module augmentation and global augmentation in the same module. 

what you can not have, is augmentation to a module that was not defined initially. you need to define the module first.
The compiler tries to look for types for `ephori` every where and could not find any. it first looks in `ephori`'s package.json for `types` property (a la `main`), then it looks for `@types/ephori` to be there and did not find that either. it also looks under your `"paths"` in your tsconfig.json if you have a redirect to `"ephori"` definition, and none was found.

the simplest way to do this is to create a new .d.ts file, e.g. `addtional.d.ts` and add:
```ts
declare module "ephori" { 
    ...
}
```

Ah, makes much more sense now. Thanks for the clarification! But I still think the error message in no way explains the issue.

The error message "[ts] Invalid module name in augmentation. Module 'ephori' resolves to an untyped module which cannot be augmented." Mentions nothing about a module not being found, and caused my misunderstanding of what was really happening, which you just corrected.
open to suggestions for a better error message.

title: Failed to launch external program tsc -p ts spawn tsc ENOENT
body:
**TypeScript Version:**  2.4.1
**VSCode Version:** 1.3.1
**OS Version:** Linux Mint 18.1
**node:** 6.11.0
**npm:** 5.0.3

Steps to Reproduce:

Open VSCode insider from Nemo or from terminal
Try to run build task **Ctrl+Shift+B** (using tsc -p in task.json 'args')

tasks.json
```javascript
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "tsc",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["-p", "ts"],
    "showOutput": "silent",
    "problemMatcher": "$tsc"
}
```

helloworld.ts in **ts** folder
```typescript
class HelloWorld {
    
}
```
tsconfig.json
```javascript
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "es5",
        "outFile": "../js/app.js",
        "sourceMap": true
    }
}
```

Empty folder **js**

**Expected behavior:**
I believe that this setup should compile the typescrpt files in my project to js files and put them in my js folder.

**Actual behavior:**
When I hit **Ctrl+Shift+B** i get: 
**Failed to launch external program tsc -p ts.**
**spawn tsc ENOENT**
in the output window

Its worth noting that if I run the **tsc** command with args in the VSCode terminal window in my projects root directory (tsc -p ts) it **DOES** seem to work fine(I get the expected behavior). 

This issues is similar to #8434 
I do have custom code in my .profile and .bashrc, but in my case it does not matter if I open from the terminal or from the file explorer

running process.env.PATH in VScode dev tools console outputs the same path as running echo $PATH from my command line.
author: kylerdanielster

comments.body:
This is normally caused by `tsc` not being in your $PATH. Double-check if your global node_modules/.bin is reachable outside of bash, e.g. via running `which tsc` in `sh`/`zsh`.

While not a fix for your issue per se, consider running the local `tsc` in your project:
```json
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "node",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["${workSpaceRoot}/node_modules/typescript/bin/tsc", "-p", "ts"],
    "showOutput": "silent",
    "problemMatcher": "$tsc"
}
```

This allows you to track the version of the TypeScript compiler you want to use in your package.json independent of the globally installed one (`npm i -g typescript`).

This worked.

Installed typescript locally with `npm i typescript` and changed tasks.json to 
```
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "node",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["{pathToWorkSpaceRoot}/node_modules/typescript/bin/tsc", "-p", "ts"],
    "showOutput": "silent",
    "problemMatcher": "$tsc"
}
```
Which as you say "allows you to track the version of the TypeScript compiler you want to use in your package.json independent of the globally installed one". Seems like a good idea. 

I think it is worth noting that: ~/.npm-global/bin is in my path which contains the tsc package. This should be equivalent to node_modules/.bin I believe. 

Regardless, running 'sh' and 'tcs' I get 'tsc: not found'.

@kylerdanielster glad it solves your issue!
Just a little addendum, since you wrote "{pathToWorkSpaceRoot}", I assume you hard-coded the path - you can use the actual string `${workSpaceRoot}` so it works regardless of where you checkout the project.

@leonadler "${workSpaceRoot}/node_modules/typescript/bin/tsc" did not work for me, that is why I hard coded it. 

I played around with the path some more and "node_modules/typescript/bin/tsc" this did the trick as well.

Current task.json (in .vscode folder)
```
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "node",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["node_modules/typescript/bin/tsc", "-p", "ts"],
    "showOutput": "silent",
    "problemMatcher": "$tsc"
}
```

title: Suggestion: syntax for overloading function expressions
body:
Currently it is only possible to define function overloads for function declarations.

Sometimes it is desirable to use function expressions instead of function declarations. It would be nice if the function overload feature was applicable to function expressions as well.

By function expression, I mean something like this:

``` ts
const identity = <X>(x: X) => x;
```

title: Unable to use boolean valued promise as thenable construct in Typescript
author: adityagautam

comments.body:
I don't know what the fix is because I don't have an isolated repro for the issue, and I don't know where you're getting the error, but I can guess.

Because TypeScript can't immediately figure out the type of the `Promise` you're constructing from its arguments, you'll need to add an explicit type argument to `new wd.promise.Promise`. Alternatively in 2.4 you'll be able to explicitly annotate the return type of `refreshElement`.

As a heads up, please use StackOverflow for "why isn't this working?" questions in the future.

title: Mapped Types Not working correctly with arrays
body:
**TypeScript Version:** 2.3.4 **Code** ```ts interface BaseType { "foo":string; "bar":number; } type MappedType = { [P in keyof BaseType]:BaseType[P][] } function addToMappedType

(mapped:MappedType, key:P, value:BaseType[P]) { let array = mapped[key]; array.push(value); } ``` **Expected behavior:** array.push should have type signature ```ts (...items:BaseType[P][])=>number``` **Actual behavior:** array.push has the type signature ```ts ((...items:string[])=>number) |((...items:number[])=>number)``` And because it lacks a unique call signature it is not able to be invoked.
author: thomasd16

comments.body:
I don't think it's clear to a developer when the type checker discards the information about the mapping it would need for the code in OP to work.

Given
- a type function `R<>`
- a homomorphic mapped type `M<>`
```ts
type M<T> = {
    [K in keyof T] : R<T[K]>
}
```
- a type `A`
- and a generic type `K extends keyof A`,

it seems like the type `M<A>[K]` should always resolve to `R<A[K]>`, *whether `A` is generic or concrete*.  But today, this only works for generic `A` and not concrete `A`.  Is this a bug, a design limitation, or working as intended?  If it's not a bug then maybe we need some documentation to explain what's going on.

title: Compiler API: How to get the "type" of an interface?
author: donaldpipowitch

comments.body:
There are two functions, `getDeclaredTypeOfSymbol` and `getTypeOfSymbol`. The former is for getting the types of *types*, the latter is for getting the types of *values*. So `getTypeOfSymbol(/*the FooProps symbol*/)` tries to get the type of the *value identifier* (variable) named `FooProps`. `getDeclaredTypeOfSymbol` will do the right thing here.

I cannot coherently explain the naming convention in a way that would let anyone intuit this behavior.
Cool, thank you again. ‚ù§

> The former is for getting the types of types

Types of types are... `interface` and `type`? So basically TypeScript keywords/primitives which aren't included in your compiled JS code?

Not sure on the first question.

For the second, there are also classes and imports to consider. The identifier for a class resolves to both a value (which is the constructor function) and a type (the instance type); similarly an `import`ed identifier *may* have both type and value meanings (or possibly neither, if it's a namespace).

title: Object types (Specification)
body:
From specification:
````
3.3 Object Types

Object types are composed from properties, call signatures, construct signatures, 
and index signatures, collectively called members.
3.8.3 Object Type Literals
  ...
  TypeMember:
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉPropertySignature
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉCallSignature
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉConstructSignature
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉIndexSignature
‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉMethodSignature
  ...
  Object type members are described in section 3.9.

3.9 Specifying Members
3.9.5 Method Signatures

  A method signature is shorthand for declaring a property of a function type.

````
Why there is no **method signatures** in the first sentence?
_Object types are composed from properties, call signatures, construct signatures, 
and index signatures, collectively called members._

Does `properties` mean `method and property signatures` together?
If so it is not evidently.
May be it is better to split `properties` into `property and method signatures`,
because we will enumerate entities from one domain (signatures).

title: [2339] Property ... does not exist on type 'typeof (Anonymous class)'
author: jhpratt

comments.body:
You are not instantiating your class `_Array`, so either you want to make `from` static or put it in an object rather than a class:
```
... 
private static _array = { from: function() {...}} ;
... 
```

` skrolr._Array` is a class, whose instances have a function called `from`. 

so either defined `from` as `static`, or call `(new skrolr._Array()).from`
Ok, yes, that was the issue. However, why does it transpile to ES6 but not ES3 without declaring `static`?

not sure what you mean by `transpile`..

the generated code is the same semantically, it just happens that on ES6 engine, your class has a static `from` method that it got from the base `Array`, on an ES3 engine, that is not the same..

in both cases, your new function goes not get to execute.

title: Confusing Types: Element, Node, HTMLElement, EventTarget
body:
**TypeScript Version:**  2.2.1

**Code**

```ts
document.activeElement.isContentEditable // type error
(document.activeElement as HTMLElement).isContentEditable

document.querySelector('[contenteditable="true"]').addEventListener("mousedown", (e) => {
	e.target.getBoundingClientRect() // type error
	(e.target as Node).getBoundingClientRect()
	(e.target as Element).getBoundingClientRect()
	(e.target as HTMLElement).getBoundingClientRect()
})
```

**Expected behavior:**

I would expect there to be no type-errors here because they all work in the browser...

**Actual behavior:**

I get random unexpected type-errors and keep having to cast types.

---

I apologize if I don't know what I'm talking about and this is actually a question, but it seems like a bug to me. If not, I'd love to see some clarification in the docs about the subtleties of these types.
author: ccorcos

comments.body:
Basically EventTarget is the most general type, of which Element is a subtype, and HTMLElement is a subtype of that. If you get back a *thing* from the DOM, we generally have no idea which it is, and you should add a type assertion to "add in" the specific external knowledge that you have about the structure of your particular DOM layout.

It's possible, for example, that the `.target` of an event is *not* an Element (you can add event listeners to XMLHttpRequest, for example, and XMLHttpRequest does not have a getBoundingClientRect method).

hmm, well in the event listener above, it seems like the target should always be HTMLElement based on the type that I'm adding the event listener to. Is it possible that we just need some stricter type annotations? Or is this just the way it is?

title: Unable to assign compatible value to generic typed property using `extends` in generic definition.
author: joslarson

comments.body:
Here is a simplified example:
```ts
class Stateful<State extends { on: boolean }> {
  state: State = {
    on: true
  }; // error
}
```
The reason this doesn't work is that it is only ever going to be valid when `Stateful` is instantiated with a type argument precisely equivalent to `{ on: boolean }`.

Basically, _there exists_ a type `T`, satisfying the constraints of `Stateful`'s type argument such that the instantiation is valid but this does not hold _for all_ types `T` where `T` satisfies the constraint of `Stateful`'s type argument.

So the errant code above asserts that, for all types `T<T>` where `T, `Stateful<T>`.

Logically, we can look at it as follows

Assertion

1. Let `P` be the type `{ on: boolean }`
2. For all types `T` such that `T` is assignable to `P`, the definition of `Stateful<T>` above is valid

Disproof by counter example
1. Let `U` be the type `{ on: boolean, value: number }`
2. `U` is assignable to `P` -> by definition
3. `Stateful<U>` is invalid -> by substitution
4. Therefore there exists a type `T` such that `T` is assignable to `P` and `Stateful<T>` is an invalid instantiation -> by implication

title: Inexplicable behavior
author: monolithed

comments.body:
**Example 1**:
It might help clarify to turn on `"noImplicitAny": true,` in your tsconfig. `1` is the *key* of the property there, and the type is omitted.
Property declarations have no effect on emit (unless they have an initializer).
FYI `readonly 1 = 2;` is totally valid code. Then `new foo()[1]` will be `2`.

**Example 2**:
`const` isn't allowed on a method (this ain't C++), so TypeScript correctly gave you an error here.
TS will still have a best-guess emit even after an error; in this case it simply ignores `const`.
Got it, thanks

title: Inference of generic type
body:
Currently a generic class such as
```ts
class A<B extends C<D>, D>
```
Must have both B and D passed when instantiated, but it would be nice if the type system could infer the type D from type B. Because if I pass in type B which extends type C<D>, then type D is known from C<D>. Why do I have to pass type D separately as well?

Or am I approaching this the wrong way? I'm just trying to avoid us having to unnecessarily import interfaces all over the place!
author: Roam-Cooper

comments.body:
Say that I define a generic class as such
```ts
class A<B<C>>
```
Is it therefore possible in any form or fashion to be able to extract type C from generic type B? Or is this impossible?

It would be incredibly, immensely useful to be able to extract the type of a generic type, especially when type mapping (another issue that I have opened).

In the nightly build there is some nice new syntactic sugar around default type arguments that allows you to omit type them from consumption sites in a number of places as well as pass down defaults which can, optionally, be themselves derived from other type arguments.

That said, I think you are after higher-kinded types, or perhaps existential types.

title: potential bug when transpiling to System.js
author: ORESoftware

comments.body:
> Perhaps this is because Object.defineProperty is not available in the browser?

`Object.defineProperty` most definitely is available in browsers.

Your code is invalid. The `system` format is not defined in terms of assignments to `module.exports` and does not provide any of `module`, `exports`, or `require`.

TypeScript throws an error on this code and the error is very specific:
> Export assignment is not supported when '--module' flag is 'system'.

Use 
```ts
export default function freezeExistingProps(obj: {}) { ... }
```
instead

title: Readonly tuple function
body:
I want to create a function that returns a tuple with literal types.

Here is what I got with TS 2.2:

``` ts
const tuple2 = <A, B>(tuple: Readonly<[A, B]>): Readonly<[A, B]> => tuple
tuple2(['foo', 'bar']) // actual Readonly<[string, string]>, expected Readonly<['foo', 'bar']>
```

Is there any way to make this return literal types?
author: OliverJAsh

comments.body:
```typescript
const tuple2 = <A extends string, B extends string>(tuple: Readonly<[A, B]>): Readonly<[A, B]> => tuple
tuple2(['foo', 'bar']) // Readonly<['foo', 'bar']>
```

I've defined a `Literal` type alias. This way the function can accept all literal values and treat them as such.

```ts
type Literal = boolean | string | number | null | undefined | object;

function pair<L extends Literal, R extends Literal>(l: L, r: R): [L, R] {
    return [l, r]
}

pair(1, 'hello');            // [1, 'hello']
pair(true, false);           // [true, false]
pair([1, 2, 3], { a: 'a' })  // [number[], { a: string }]
pair(/test/, 'value')        // [RegExp, 'value']
pair(null, undefined)        // [null, undefined]
```
Thanks all!

title: static types checking not working properly when retrieving values from the array
body:
**TypeScript Version:**  2.2.1 

**Code**

```ts
var values :any[] =["a", "b", 1 ,2, true, false];

var fname :number =values[0];

console.log(typeof(fname));
```

title: Path resolution after build
author: jonathanroze

comments.body: not sure that  I understand the problem correctly. Path mappings were introduced to address the issue with flexible module loading in runtime when loader can map module id from the source code to a physical file using some additional configuration (i.e. via `paths` section in SystemJS or RequireJs). Module imports are never altered by the compiler - it assumes that whatever was written by user is correct and will apply`baseUrl`, `paths` and `rootDirs` to map this module id to a file to be used as type infor for module in design time.
@vladima  Mhhh ok i understand but, when i compile my code how can i change this path by absolute path ? :/ !
Presumablly you have a babel-plugin or some post-build script that updates the reference. the setting here is just to "tell" the compiler what happens at build time.
Ok great ! Thanks for your help :-)

title: When using the native method 'defineProperty ' to define a 'Getter' for a class, the compiler error!
author: ulivz

comments.body: Can the name of interface and class be the same name? well, I didn‚Äòt write it before. Just wrote a simple `interface inheritance`

> Can the name of interface and class be the same name?

It takes advantage of what TypeScript calls "interface merging".  When an interface and a class have the same name, it automatically merges the two.  This is in part why it is often recommended not to name your interfaces with an `I...` which is a convention in many other languages, since there some "automagic" that can happen when the names are the same.

It is best to think as the type system in TypeScript as an "overlay" on top of the underlying JavaScript.

Also to properly type your interface, you should be marking properties that only have a getter as `readonly` in the interface, which will disallow assignment to the properties within the type system, which would more accurately reflect your runtime intent.

title: bugs:strange primitive types
author: holi-java

comments.body:
The reflect metadata tries to represent types at design time at runtime. This is a lossy processes by definition, since there are types that only exist in design time (e.g. interfaces, type aliases, etc..).

The way this works is for primitives, the boxed values are uses to serialize them:
* `number` => `Number`
* `string` => `String`
* `boolean` => `Boolean`
* `object` => `Object`
* Arrays are always serialized to `Array`
* Classes will be serialized as themselves, since they do exist at run time
* function types will be serialized as `Function`
* Everything else will be serialized as `Object`

Hope this answers your question.

title: Unable to parameterize keyof (in function) to access object's fields
author: vladimir-djokic

comments.body:
In your example, `keyof INested1` is equivalent to `"id" | "name" | "nested2a" | "nested2b"` (the full set of property names for `INested1`). You need to restrict it to just `"nested2a" | "nested2b"`:

```ts
function foo1param(f: IFoo, nested2key: "nested2a" | "nested2b"): void { ... }
```

Once you do that your example works.
I understand now, thank you! I guess this was a classic case of _"can't see the forest for the trees"_.

title: String not assignable to string enum even when value is known at compile time and is part of the enum.
author: realyze

comments.body: FWIW, `bar.fun({foo: 'enum1'})` compiles OK.
I would suggest `defaults` type to be inferred as `{ foo: string & 'enum1' }` rather than `string`.

Note that `defaults.foo` is mutable, so the inferred type has to be `string`; otherwise it would prevent you from ever mutating it. Using `&` is even more dangerous as, if you _did_ mutate it, the `& 'enum1'` part of the type would make its type be `'enum1'` even if it was any other value.

You probably want something similar to this, probably with an `interface` or `type` alias to avoid repetition:

```ts
const defaults: { foo: 'enum1' | 'enum2' } = {
  foo: 'enum1'
}
```
@Kovensky Right, hmm, yeah that does make sense. I'll close this. Thanks!

It seems like `tsc` does not consider `string`s like `"cors"` or `"default"` to be of the types `RequestMode` or `RequestCache`, unless one adds the type declaration as @ubershmekel did in their answer.

author: krryan

comments.body: Currently reachability analysis in compiler works on the statement level which has a good rationale: it is pretty common to have code like `while(true) <block>` where control flow inside the loop can be abrupted via `return`, `break`, `continue` or `throw` statements. However having it on the expression level add a very little value to the real world use-cases, i.e. what is the purpose of writing  code like `true ? <do-something> : <do-something-else>` other than making synthetic example?

title: Avoid "cannot assign an abstract constructor ..." through union type
author: hediet

comments.body:
The type `{ new(): T } | Function` is equivalent to `Function` because `{ new(): T }` is assignable to `Function` (the same way the type `Dog | Animal` is equivalent to `Animal`). We call this "subtype reduction" and in general it's really bad to write down a type that undergoes immediate reduction (we probably should have made this an error when we made union types, but too late now).

Most of the time when people write `Function` the actual type they want is `(...args: any[]) => any)`:
```ts
`function test2<T>(arg: { new(): T } | ((...args: any[]) => any) ): T { return null!; }

const b = test2(Test); // Error
```

Thanks for your answer!
But still, the type of the expression `test2(Test)` infers to `Test`. If `{ new():T } | Function` is actually equivalent to `Function`, TypeScript should have inferred `any`, as it does for `test3(Test)` in
```ts
function test3<T>(arg: Function): T { return null!; }
```
However, I like TypeScripts current inference behavior as it solves #5843. I need this for my remoting library that instantiates abstract classes (which need to be classes so they can be decorated with metadata).

title: semver guidelines for libraries with typings
body:
This is a discussion tailor to JavaScript libraries distributing their own typings.

Changing typings can easily break builds, even if the underlying JavaScript code doesn't change.

We should have a guideline to describe when should it be considered a minor/major version bump.

On the other hand, since the JavaScript code doesn't change (or only worth a patch version bump), if we recommend to bump minor/major version when the typings changes, the consumer who consumes the library in JavaScript project could be confused by these version changes because there are no code changes to them.
author: unional

comments.body:
If you own the package, and you include the declaration files with your package, then you should follow semver for your .d.ts files just like you do for your .js files. 

if the declaration file change is breaking, then it should be under a major version, otherwise use a minor version. 

This means that you can be shipping new versions the package that differ only in .d.ts content, but that is no different from any other non-js resources that your package can carry, e.g. package.json or .css files.

Agree to what you say, but may not fly for the package authors because they may think typings (and flow definitions) are additional and have a different point of view.

Is education the only option?
The other option is to build a while different system for getting definitions. we believe npm is a good system to use, it saves the users from learning about a new system altogether.

title: Unsafe coercion from "any type" to {}
body:
**TypeScript Version:**  2.1.5 and 2.2.0-dev.20170201
Using --noImplicitAny and --strictNullChecks

**Code**

```ts
function doItWithAnObject<A extends {}>(a: A) {
  a.toString()
}

function doItWithAnything<B>(b: B) {
  doItWithAnObject(b)
}

doItWithAnything(null)
doItWithAnything(undefined)
```

**Expected behavior:**
`doItWithAnything` should not compile because it calls `doItWithAnObject` with something that is potentially not an object.

**Actual behavior:**
No compilation error. Runtime errors.

Perhaps related: If I have an abstract type A, and I narrow it down to A minus null minus undefined, it isn't considered as an object.
author: AlexGalays

comments.body: if you want to exclude `null` and `undefined`, give the generic type parameter a constraint for `{}`. if you want to further exclude primitives, give it a constraint `object`. otherwise, it goes to the top type, i.e. `{} | null | undefined`
Oh, I see. Thanks.

title: Invoking methods from object iteration
author: DataTables

comments.body:
Thanks! Yes, that allows a clean compile with tsc 2.1.5.

So I guess the question becomes, is the 2.0 or 2.1 behaviour correct?

The current behavior is correct. The call without a type assertion is clearly not type safe, but previously we were not equipped to track the type of a computed property access so we would give an implicit `any` type to `this[prop]` (and you'd get an error with `--noImplicitAny`). Now, because of indexed access types (a.k.a. "lookup types") we can do a better job.

Awesome - thanks very much.

Others have said it many times, and I as well, but going to say it again - TypeScript is excellent and a credit to all involved!

title: files/dirs that start with a dot (.) do not get copied or transpiled by default
body:
**TypeScript Version:**  2.1.4

**Code**

```
/lib
/test
    /.suman
    /test-src
```

if I build this project with `tsc` and use the outDir option, the .suman directory **won't** get moved/transpiled, presumably because it starts with a dot .

based on the above project structure, the resulting _incorrect_ build would look like:

```
/dist
   /lib
   /test
       /test-src  
```
above we can see that the .suman dir is missing from the test dir

if I rename the .suman directory to suman like so:

```
/lib
/test
    /suman    // renamed from .suman to suman
    /test-src
```

then it will get moved to the outDir, because it no longer starts with a dot .

so the expected result actually happens, which is of course:

```
/dist
   /lib
   /test
       /suman
       /test-src
```




here is my config, which shows that I want to `include` my test dir, in the build.

```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "compileOnSave": true,
    "target": "es5",
    "noImplicitAny": false,
    "removeComments": true,
    "preserveConstEnums": true,
    "outDir": "dist",
    "allowJs": true,
    "allowUnreachableCode": true,
    "lib": ["es2015", "dom"]
  },
  "include": [
    "./**/*"
  ],
  "exclude": [
    "node_modules"
  ]
}

```

**Expected behavior:**

I would expect it would include files/directories that start with a dot, unless you exclude files/dirs that start with a dot

**Actual behavior:**

TS/tsc seems to exclude files/dirs that start with a dot by default, which seems very strange, since users could easily specify with a regex to ignore dirs/files that start with a dot!

**My question is then, is there a tsconfig.json setting I can use to include the .suman directory with my build?**
author: ORESoftware

comments.body:
files and folders starting with a `.` are ignored by the glob patterns. this to accomodate for hidden folders that tools like git rely on. You need to add the folder starting with a `.` explcitlly in your include patter:

```json
  "include": [
    "./**/*",
    "./test/.suman/**/*"
  ],
```

also one note, you need to exclude your outDir, or you will be consuming the output again, given that you have `--allowJs` set. so your exclude patterns should be:
```json
  "exclude": [
    "node_modules",
    "./dist"
  ]
```
ahh thanks so much that helps a ton!

title: An index signature parameter type must be 'string' or 'number' - why not string | number?
author: danielearwicker

comments.body:
Yes. `number` is convertible to `string`, so really (in the first example) `string | number` would effectively be equivalent to `string`, so in truth the existing behaviour doesn't help that much in the simple case, though with `--noImplicitAny` the reverse is properly caught.

This looseness extends to access via union key type:

```ts
declare const m: { [key: string ]: boolean};
declare const k: string | number;

m[k] = true;
```

However, the generic case (which is what I'm actually interested in) is a bit tighter:

```ts
function foo<K extends string | number>(k: K) {

    var m: { [key: string ]: boolean}; // try using string as workaround

    m[k] = true; // type K cannot be used to index...
}
```

So the indexer key type is `string`, and K is one of `(string|number)`, `string`, `number`, all of which are fine outside generics. But instead it errors.

So the complete workaround is to use `string` as the key type *and* stick in a type assertion `m[k as string]` everywhere you use the indexer. Or equivalently, use `number` and use `m[k as number]` everywhere. It doesn't matter which one you pick, as in the generic case the convertibility of `number` to `string` does not appear to be relevant.

My guess is that if an indexer could be declare with a generic key type, as long as that key type was one of `(string|number)`, `string`, `number`, then no workaround would be needed.

title: Performance Query - Large String Union Types
body:
## Background 

We have a 2000 line localization file, and a localize function in our code which pulls out the translation at run-time.

I am investigating the possibility of auto-generating a large string union type, writing it out to a file, and using it as a type parameter for the localize function.

## Code

**TypeScript Version:**  2.1.4

**Before**

```ts
function localize(id: string) {
   // ...
}

localize('not a real key'); // OK
```

**After**

```ts
function localize(id: LocalizationKey) {
   // ...
}

localize('not a real key'); // NOT OK

// auto-generated
type LocalizationKey =
    "foo"
  | "bar"
  | ... // 2000+ items.
```

This works fine.

## Question

We are concerned about type-checking performance, both at compile time, and in TypeScript language services in our IDEs (VS Code and Visual Studio).

Is this a valid concern, or will these types be cached in an efficient manner?

Thanks.
author: azz

comments.body: Closing this as it doesn't seem to be an issue.

FYI - Large unions of literal types are highly optimized because that's the internal representation of an enum value. We have an enum in the compiler with ~350 members and it doesn't cause any problems (that I'm aware of). 2,000 might be pushing it but I suspect you'll be OK.

title: Multiple recommendations / Issues related to TS development under Visual Studio
body:
Hello, I have multiple recommendations to typescript (and ts for visual studio). I am using it in the similar way as the C# so I split classes to separate files and compiling each project to the single library file (or "executable"), referencing projects in the solution as libraries and so on. I have found few things I don't like so much, but in the worst case I can live with them :) On the other hand it would be great if these can be fixed. All are related to web development, not to dev for Node, but its not probably important.

Visual Studio

a) Multiple VS projects in single solution
   If there are multiple projects in the solution and one project is used as a library (js+.d.ts) in the second it is not possible to navigate directly to source code of the library (by pressing F12) but navigation to the .d.ts file is performed instead. It would be great if there can be some internal mapping mechanism and the right the source file / type is openned directly.

b) Debugging
   If the "dynamic script" (in meaning it was evaled or loaded dynamically by injecting a script tag) is about to be debugged and the source is not located directly in the main project (the js library with a map file is loaded) it is not possible to see the content of variables using a mouse over method. Breakpoints works well, watches too, but it would be great if mouse over can work too in such case. It is strange that when I switch from the dynamic code to the source I can hover, but I can't debug, because stepping forward switches me back to the dynamic of course.

TypeScript

a) Namespaces
   If there is a same namespace splited over multiple files and the transpilation target is single file it is necessary to use export keyword in order to make definitions in a one file available through other files but with the same namespace. This is strange behavior, but I get it is related to modules loaded separately.

b) Namespaces transpillation
   If the namespace with the same name is used and splitted over multiple files and the single transpillation target is used it would be great to join all the same namespaces together to the single literal. Currently, there are as many namespaces as files defining them.

If you will find any of my recommendations "fixable" I can create separate issues for them.

Regards,
Frantisek Novak
author: atomsoftwarestudios

comments.body:
Regarding Visual Studio b)
I have recreated the solution and now everything works as expected. But at this time I was not able to identify where the problem was. I'll keep you updated if I'll identify it.
üëç for item a) it's badly needed but it has nothing to do with Visual Studio. It has to do with the concept of package level references that mean more than simply files on disk.
I can imagine this will be hard as if the source will not be available in the solution this can bring problems. I can live with it, its not that big deal, find feature works well too ;)

title: Œª return object
body:
let func=(val:number)=>{x:val};//error
let func=(val:number)=>{return {x:val};};//ok
author: kgtkr

comments.body:
The first line is, unfortunately , a valid JS grammar production. the `{}` represent the body of the function, the `x` is a label, the `val` is an expression, the function as a whole implicitly returns `undefined`.

you can wrap it in parans to avoid this. e.g. 
```ts
let func1 = (val: number) => ({ x: val });
```
thank you

title: Conflict between  Intersection types and keyof
author: WanderWang

comments.body: This looks correct to me. Your signature is saying `{ [key: string]: number }` is valid, so any key not in `T` must be a number (and anything in `T` intersects with `number` so makes some `never` types when `string & number`. Perhaps you want a signature more like `Partial<{ [X in keyof T]: number }>`? If `{ text: 1 }` is definitely meant to be an error, try the signature `Partial<T & { [X in keyof T]: number }>`, I couldn't really tell if the error there was intentional.

Thanks !!!
``` Partial<T & { [X in keyof T]: number }> ``` it worked well !!!! I think this issue should be closed

title: Implementing interface is not required for class children?
author: pie6k

comments.body: The implementation is provided by the base class. Child classes inherit it automatically.
What if I want parent class to be `abstract` and require child classes to implement interface, or in case they override parent class, to keep overrides following parent interface?

Then you would decorate each method in the base class with the `abstract` modifier. Alternatively you could declare that the child class implements the base class as supposed to be deriving from it, or both.

**EDIT** fixed insane typo (hunting -> deriving) due to speech to text engine üòÜ

TypeScript has a structural type system. at every location where a type is expected, the value is checked it it matches the expected type. the check depends on the structure, and not if type has an `implements` clause. 

The only use of an `implement` clause, is to ask the compiler to give you an error if your class does not implement the interface. the class does not get any additional properties by implementing an interface.

title: bug: type predicates (`V is T`) fails on expressions (`V[K] is T`)
body:
**TypeScript Version:** nightly (2.2.0-dev.20161128)

**Code**

```ts
propIs<T, V, K extends keyof V>(type: T, name: K, obj: V): V[K] is T;
```

**Expected behavior:**
TS being totally cool with `V[K] is T`.

**Actual behavior:**
Nope, many syntax errors.
author: KiaraGrouwstra

comments.body: The type predicate syntax has always taken a parameter name on the left side of the `is` keyword. So it sounds like what you want is better parser recovery here.

Oh, yeah, `V is T` itself works fine, this seems to be specifically about adding the `[K]` there. It does seem like storing (`extends`) `V[K]` in a new generic may form a solution here...
But apparently `propIs<T, V, K extends keyof V, R extends V[K]>(type: T, name: K, obj: V): R is T;` yields `Cannot find parameter 'R'`. I must be doing something wrong...

I'm sorry, that would be my misinterpretation then.
In that event I would be inclined to try the following for this specific case:
```ts
propIs<T, V, K extends keyof V, R extends V[K]>(type: T, name: K, obj: V): obj[name] is T;
```
Still not okay though. I suppose it'd help if I had the ability to save this result to a new variable first, but I'm not confident I can do this in the type language...

You could do something like this:

```ts
propIs<T, V, K extends keyof V, R extends V[K]>(type: T, name: K, obj: V): obj is (V & Record<K, T>)
```
Whoa, some out of the box thinking there, wouldn't have come up with that myself. Thanks for thinking along. :)

You uses UriMapHandlerArray as a value of uri_map property not as a type.

If you want to define IUriMap type as { uri_map: UriMapHandlerArray } you can do:
`type IUriMap = { uri_map: UriMapHandlerArray }`

```
export class Furi {

}
```

title: async/await with arrow functions compiles to invalid javascript with SyntaxError
body:
<!-- BUGS: Please use this template. -->
**TypeScript Version:**  2.0.9

**Code**
```ts
test('smoke', async t => {
	await Promise.resolve();
});
```

**Expected behavior:**
No SyntaxError.

**Actual behavior:** 
```js
test('smoke', function (t) __awaiter(this, void 0, void 0, function* () {
    yield Promise.resolve();
}));
```
```
  SyntaxError: test.js: Unexpected token, expected { (47:27)
  45 |     t.pass();
  46 | });
> 47 | test('smoke', function (t) __awaiter(this, void 0, void 0, function* () {
     |                            ^
  48 |     yield Promise.resolve();
  49 | }));
  50 | test('save', function (t) {
```

But general function (non-async) compiles to valid javascript.
```
test('smoke', async function (t) {
	await Promise.resolve();
});
```
```
test('smoke', function (t) {
    return __awaiter(this, void 0, void 0, function* () {
        yield Promise.resolve();
    });
});
```
author: unlight

comments.body:
You should be getting an error message that TypeScript 2.0 can't target ES5 when using async functions, so the incorrect emit is expected.

In 2.1, this will be fixed. You can use the 2.1 release candidate by running

```
npm install -g typescript@rc
```

or use our nightlies by running

```
npm install -g typescript@next
```
Also check out #7706.

title: importHelpers does not emit import unless at least one other import is present
body:
Noticed on a webpack project with typescript@2.1.1, using either commonjs or es2015 modules:

```ts
// index.ts

import './empty'

async function x () {}
```

```ts
// empty.ts
```

This emits an import for `tslib` following by the import for `empty`. However, commenting the `import 'empty'` line out also omits the import for `tslib`, and the emitted code attempts to use a global `__awaiter`.

I thought this might have been fixed by #12151, but it's still present in current `master` (built with `gulp LKG`).
author: Jessidhia

comments.body:
Using `isolatedModules` gives a clue: the "Cannot compile namespaces" error hints that tsc doesn't/can't treat files without `import`/`export` as a module.

With `isolatedModules` enabled, putting an `export {}` is enough to pass the `isolatedModules` condition, and the code is emitted with the `tslib` import.
Just wasted two hours on this! With an empty import statement, it works as intended. Tested on version `2.2.0-dev.20170110`

If the file does not have a toplevel import/export is it is not considered a module, and it is treated as script/global.

use `--isolatedModules` to flag these files as errors.

```ts
            } else if (ts.SyntaxKind.IfStatement === node.kind || 1+1 !== 2){

        default:

    }
    console.log(`${node.getSourceFile().fileName} (${line + 1},${character + 1})::kind=${kind}:: ${message}`);
}
function doNode(node: ts.Node) {
    report(node, node.getText());
    ts.forEachChild(node, doNode);
}
function compile(fileNames: string[], options: ts.CompilerOptions): void {
    let program = ts.createProgram(fileNames, options);
    curTypeChecker = program.getTypeChecker();
    let emitResult = program.emit();
    let allDiagnostics = ts.getPreEmitDiagnostics(program).concat(emitResult.diagnostics);
    allDiagnostics.forEach(diagnostic => {
        if (diagnostic.file) {

            let { line, character } = diagnostic.file.getLineAndCharacterOfPosition(diagnostic.start);
            let message = ts.flattenDiagnosticMessageText(diagnostic.messageText, '\n');
            console.log(`--diagnostic--${diagnostic.file.fileName} (${line + 1},${character + 1}): ${message}`);
        } else {
            console.log(`--diagnostic.code=${diagnostic.code}`);
        }
    });
    var curSource: ts.SourceFile = program.getSourceFile(fileNames[0]);
     doNode(curSource);
    console.log(`Diagnostics count= '${allDiagnostics.length}'.`);
    let exitCode = emitResult.emitSkipped ? 1 : 0;
    console.log(`Process exiting with code '${exitCode}'.`);
    process.exit(exitCode);
}

console.log("begin")
process.argv.forEach((v,i,a)=>{
    console.log(v);
})
compile(process.argv.slice(2), {
    noEmitOnError: true, noImplicitAny: true,
    target: ts.ScriptTarget.ES5, module: ts.ModuleKind.CommonJS
});
console.log("normal end")

```

title: typescript change number when cast from json
body:
i am geting json data from a web api as the following  :
{"name":"johan","packageNo":[100000498827944537]}
but when i use it in typeScript project the packageNo change to number : 100000498827944540
Whyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy?
author: itsurge

comments.body:
It's not related to typescript. it's simply how javascript handles number.
The maximum safely representable integer in javascript is 9007199254740991 which is a couple of zeroes smaller than your number. no wonder it gets messy. don't cast this to number, you can't represent it. use `string` instead.

``` js
9007199254740991    // max safe
100000498827944540  // your number :O
```

Just to clarify TypeScript does not perform typecasting at all. What you think of as casting is actually type assertion. It is purely a design time feature and has no impact on the code that is either emitted or executed.

title: TS is incorrectly disallowing a variable assignment.
author: DeegC

comments.body:
>  It appears that TS thinks that EntityInstance as specified in "EntityArray<EntityInstance>" is a different type from EntityInstance

It is. You declared a type parameter that shadowed the name:

``` ts
class EntityArray<EntityInstance> extends Array<EntityInstance> {
```

You probably meant to write

``` ts
class EntityArray extends Array<EntityInstance> {
```

Or perhaps this:

``` ts
class EntityArray<T extends EntityInstance> extends Array<T> {
```

Thanks Ryan, that solved my problem.  It does seem like a confusing error message; would it be possible to flag the original `EntityArray<EntityInstance>` as an error for attempting to create a type with an already-existing name?

Either way, I appreciate the help.

Shadowing is, for better or worse, a part of JavaScript that is fairly ubiquitous. Of course these are types, not Java Script values but it makes sense that the same naming rules would apply. Maybe just displaying that it's a type parameter in the error message would be helpful.

It's kind of necessary to allow type name shadowing, otherwise we wouldn't be able to safely add things to the global namespace without the risk of a breaking change.

There's perhaps a suggestion lurking here which is that our error messages should do something (I don't know what) if we ever issue a message like "Cannot assign X to X" where both X's have identical spelling. I mean ideally you'd see something like "Cannot assign X (Type Parameter) to X (Interface)", but it's hard to guess if even that would cover all the cases.

> There's perhaps a suggestion lurking here which is that our error messages should do something (I don't know what) if we ever issue a message like "Cannot assign X to X" where both X's have identical spelling. I mean ideally you'd see something like "Cannot assign X (Type Parameter) to X (Interface)", but it's hard to guess if even that would cover all the cases.

@RyanCavanaugh I was going to suggest this at first but there are a lot of lenses via which to look at a type so it could become ambiguous, or a just a best guess, in a lot of cases. 

Maybe a simpler, higher value option would be to do something like

``` scala
given Types A and B over assignment
where not A assignable to B
report IncompatableAssignementOfIdenticallyNamedTypesDiagnostic
when A name is B name
otherwise report IncompatibleTypesDiagnostic
```

So it would say something like **"Type 'B' is not assignable to type 'A'. (note that they are _not_ same Declaration)"**

Would it be possible to make it illegal for the name of a generic type to shadow a previously defined type?  I'm obviously no TS expert (yet!) but I can't think of a reason one would need to shadow a currently existing type.  The error message could be something like "Generic type name 'EntityInstance' not allowed because it would shadow an existing type.'

That would potentially break some current client code; if that's forbidden maybe make it a warning?

title: QUESTION: Advanced intersection type
body:
Hi, we are preparing typings fro the amazing semantic-ui-react project.

One of the properties of the library is the possibility to define how the element will be rendered.
For example:

``` js
<Button>Text</Button>
```

is rendered as

``` js
<button class="ui button">Text</button>
```

But, if I want to make a link button I can do (note the **as** param)

``` js
<Button as="a" href="/">Text</Button>
```

is rendered as

``` js
<a class="ui button" href="/">Text</button>
```

Now, the problem is, that I do not know how to merge the typings based on the property specified in the "as" element.

What we have is this:

``` js
interface ButtonProps {
...
}

interface ButtonStatic extends React.StatelessComponent<IButtonProps> {
}

export const Button: ButtonStatic;
```

The idea is do do following, but the T needs to come from attribute "as":

``` js
interface ButtonStatic<T> extends React.StatelessComponent<IButtonProps & T> {
}

export const Button: ButtonStatic;
```

I pretty much know it won't be possible this way, but do you have any idea on how can I tell the element that it needs to merge props with another interface?

Thanks

title: Question: Why are some of the CompilerOptions Internal?
body: I am upgrading my bundling Typescript compiler to use Typescript 2.x and noticed that a number of CompilerOptions ares now internal ( Diagnostics, ListFiles, Watch, etc ). Is there a reason for this?
author: ToddThomson

comments.body: These are options that are used only by commandline compiler driver (tsc.js), no other parts of the system use them, so specifying them would be not be useful. e.g. `help`. setting this on the API does not do any thing.

I use them. For example when doing white space elimination I use the Diagnostics flag to output white space reduction statistics. I also need to know if the user has the Watch flag set as I have compile and bundling and minification functions that result when a source file changes.
I agree that these settings are most likely only used by those of us writing features on top of the transpiler, but they are needed.

Nothing stops you from defining a new property on the option bag. Your diagnostics flag means something to you, so that is fine, but it is not the same meaning the one in types has. So my recomedation is to add your declarations on top of the exisitng compileroptions as needed.

Yes, I see your point, I am just piggybacking my use of a few of the "internal" compiler options.
In any event, as you say, it is simple enough to get those properties back for my use. Cheers, @mhegazy
